pageElements.text: From back in the days when people subjected one another to interminable slide shows of their trips abroad, the vacation photo has been an essential souvenir to bring home. But how often have you come home from an unforgettable trip only to realize that you have no good photos of the whole family together?

Smartphones make it easier than to take snapshots, but it's a lot harder than it looks to capture both the people and the overall feeling of a place by snapping away with your iPhone. Theme parks have been exploiting that need for years, sending marginally qualified employees out with cameras to take a smiling group photo, say in front of the entrance to Sea World—and then sell you a hastily developed photo for a ridiculous price. (I've bought them anyway.)

A new service called Flytographer could be the fix for the photo issue. This website will set you up with a half-hour, one-hour, or two-hour photo session at your vacation spot with a professional photographer. The result: studio-quality shots that will really serve as treasured mementos of your vacation.

Flytographer is relatively new, having launched less than a year ago. Founder Nicole Smith said she was inspired by a trip to Paris, when she and a friend got someone to take good photos of them strolling around the city. She now has photographers lined up in seventy cities. The most booked locations so far have been New York City, Hawaii, and Disneyland, but you can book all over the world, from Melbourne to Bangkok to Copenhagen and from Buenos Aires to Vancouver.

In a half-hour shoot ($250), you get shots in one location and fifteen digital photos. For $350, you can get photos in one or two locations or neighborhoods and go home with thirty digital images. For $600, you can be photographed in multiple locations around your vacation spot and get sixty digital images. And, yes, you will be in the family photos this time, not behind the camera. Kind of makes you want to plan a trip somewhere glamorous, doesn't it?

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: I am helping Martina Kohl unload a handsome vanity from her car; somehow she has managed to fit the unwieldy piece of furniture into her beloved silver Toyota Prius. We lift the Art Deco table and mirror that she has purchased from a bankruptcy sale of the estate of Dr. Arnold Klein, the controversial dermatologist of the late Michael Jackson, and carry it into her home in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles.

Austria-born Martina is a prominent Hollywood makeup artist (but no, she never worked on Michael Jackson). She has performed her movie magic on faces belonging to Oscar winners John Travolta, Vanessa Redgrave, Ralph Fiennes, and Glenn Close. She’s also responsible for numerous temporary transfer tattoos on the FX TV series Sons of Anarchy.

Martina’s 2004 Toyota Prius hatchback, while tattoo free, was from the first batch of gasoline-electric hybrids that looked like Prii as we know them today, attractive and spacious.  When Martina first heard about the new model, she immediately ordered one.  She says, “I wanted something better for the environment and to make a difference.” Other Angelenos felt the same way, and there were waiting lists at all the Toyota dealers in the vicinity, some dealerships even insisting that prospective buyers place a $1,000 deposit to be entered onto their lists.  And pay and wait she did.  Martina requested the car in black, but while blues and reds cropped up, no one seemed to have a black Prius for her. So finally, after four months, she heard about a silver one at the Toyota dealer in the nearby city of West Covina and said she’d take it.
When she first drove the 2004 Toyota Prius, she’d notice people waving and signaling from nearby vehicles. "It was such a sensation then," Martina remembers.

When she first drove the Prius, she’d notice people waving and signaling from nearby vehicles.  She remembers: “There would be a car next to me pulling up, and I’d wonder, Why are they looking at me?  And they would point, and I would think maybe they wanted to get in the lane in front of me.  What do they want?  And they’d signal for me to roll my window down.  How strange!  Then they’d call, ‘How is your car?’  I realized I had something really special.  It was such a sensation then!”

Other drivers would have had good reason to suffer from Prius envy! For four years, the City of Los Angeles allowed hybrids free meter parking, and until 2011, the State of California even granted Martina’s car the privilege of traveling in carpool lanes with a single occupant, a benefit it still bestows on certain clean alternative-fuel vehicles.

As a makeup artist, Martina must transport herself not just to the studios but from location to location all over Southern California. Even though she is adamant that she purchased the car for environmental reasons rather than economical ones, she has definitely saved large sums of money on fuel in the decade since purchasing her Prius.
The standard mid-size car would have gulped roughly $11,700 worth of gas in ten years;  Martina’s Prius has sipped around $6,300 of fuel from the pump.

To find out just how much good she has done for the environment and her pocketbook, I contacted Toyota product specialist Maurice Durand.  He told me that with a standard car getting around 25 mpg and the 2004 Prius averaging 46 mpg, Martina’s car would have required roughly 1,650 fewer gallons of gas, having accumulated 90,000 miles over ten years.  Put into dollar figures, employing a conservative median price of  $3.25 per gallon, Martina has saved herself close to $5,400. The standard mid-size car would have gulped roughly $11,700 worth of gas in ten years;  Martina’s Prius has sipped around $6,300 of fuel from the pump.
And she reports that the car has been absolutely reliable, with no mechanical problems in the ten years she’s owned it.

While Martina says her vehicle is quiet, comfortable, and fun to drive, she finds herself doing something she had never done with previous cars, her last one being a Mercedes 300E. She says, “When driving, I now always look at my screen. Where am I with my mileage? What am I getting? You always watch the battery.”

Martina’s silver Prius, assembled in Japan, features a 1.5-liter engine that makes 76 horsepower and a continuously variable automatic transmission. The 2004 model garnered great results on safety tests—four or five stars on NHTSA crash tests—and although it takes ten seconds to accelerate from 0 to 60 mph, it comes with excellent regenerative braking and four-wheel ABS. Its four-door body seats five, and Martina’s vehicle has all-electric air conditioning, a six-speaker stereo, a navigation system, cruise control, power steering, remote keyless entry, a rear wiper, and the aforementioned energy monitor. Her car has front, front side, and side head curtain airbags. The Prius came with a 36,000-mile three year bumper-to-bumper warranty, with the hybrid component guaranteed for eight years or 100,000 miles. There is plenty of legroom, and the back seats fold down, so Martina can carry all sorts of objects, including the tools of her profession and an Art Deco vanity.

Martina has been a makeup artist for the good-looking passengers in a number of automobile commercials, including ads for Audi, Citroën, Dodge, Jaguar, Mini Cooper, Renault, Volkswagen, and Toyota (although not for a Toyota Prius).

Martina doesn’t always apply cosmetics to render people more attractive. Her latest picture, Low Down, just nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at the 2014 Sundance Film Festival, is a study of drug-addled and destitute denizens of the 1960s and 1970s jazz world. Martina needed to take such appealing and normally healthy-looking actors as Lena Headey, Elle Fanning, Peter Dinklage, John Hawkes, and Taryn Manning and create wan, mottled, and bumpy complexions.
But the silver complexion and healthy body of her 2004 Prius are holding up very well.

contributors.bio:
My return to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee during the Reagan era for a second bachelor’s degree accomplished two things: I made writing for a car magazine a career goal, and I met my future wife, though it took Donna two decades to come around to the latter idea. Over that quarter-century, I went on to write general assignment stories for the Milwaukee Sentinel, became a cop reporter, then schools reporter and film critic for the Quad-City Times, where I also covered Cary Grant’s death in Davenport, Iowa, and then I worked for the San Diego Business Journal, where I became an expert on the arcane America’s Cup Deed of Gift. When I moved to Washington, D.C., where I wrote about the Clinton health care reform plan and other Capitol Hill issues for an inside-the-beltway newsletter publisher, I thought I had found my true calling. Matt DeLorenzo convinced me otherwise, and I moved to Detroit in 1996 to work for AutoWeek. Four years later, Jack Keebler lured me to Motor Trend, where I wrote news and rumors about future cars, voted in a dozen (each) Car of the Year and Sport/Utility of the Year competitions, and blogged as the Motor City Blogman. Detroit is to the global auto industry what Washington is to national politics. It’s easily more fascinating and as frustrating to cover as a journalist. The commute is far more interesting.

My years at Motor Trend, working side-by-side with Technical Director Frank Markus, have been enormously fulfilling. I’ve become fully immersed in the nuts and bolts of cars, and the industry. You have to keep a love for cars and driving in perspective. For me, Donna, our two collies, and my family back in Wisconsin come first. I can be nearly as passionate about politics, movies and art, and the Green Bay Packers, of which I’m a shareholder. My favorite sport is still Formula 1, though.

Automobile is about living with cars, both the good ones and the bad ones, but most importantly, the most interesting ones. With autonomous cars on the near horizon, we face the greatest threat to our enthusiasm since the malaise and oil embargoes of the ‘70s, the era when I earned my driver’s license. With Jean, Joe and their crew, Automobile already has the best, most interesting writers to explain why you should put down that mobile phone and grab the steering wheel. I’m thrilled to become part of this team and I look forward to helping place the cars and the way we drive them in context.

pageElements.text: From the land of Swiss army knives and overpriced watches comes the 84th International Salon de l’Auto, every car fan's favorite show. The PalExpo here is neutral ground for cars, too, with no one nation dominating the compact, easy-to-walk dual halls, though a “bilingual” stand more often has French and German, not English, spoken first.

From the show stand's spokesmodels, you can usually tell the given automaker’s provenance. The Italian stands, Fiat, Alfa Romeo, Lancia, Maserati, and Ferrari, have unabashedly sexy spokesmodels in slinky black garb. The French are more elegant and, well, uniquely French. One model at the Peugeot stand even wore, somewhat stereotypically, a black beret as part of an art display for the new 108 supermini hatchback. At the Mini stand nearby, male and female stand personnel wore black derby hats, recalling Stanley Kubrick’s A Clockwork Orange as much as Old Blighty.

Would that Mini’s new product matched that film’s (or book’s) edginess; along with the new Audi TT in the adjacent hall, the Mini Clubman concept proved how hard it is to remain avant garde twelve or fifteen years after your original breakthrough. Like, say, a W Hotel, sometimes a renovation is simply a renovation.
Enter, then, the French. They provided two cars designed for quotidian use that truly make some breakthroughs. Here's a quick tour.

Small Family Car with Personality: Citroen C4 Cactus

Citroen showed a tarted-up “off road” all-wheel-drive version of its new wagonette, named the C4 Cactus Adventure. But the standard, production C4 Cactus would have been enough.

Based on the C4 line of four-cylinder compacts, the Cactus features a fresh and modern interior with good materials and padded door armrests, and Air Bump door panels: outer door panels are covered with soft, rubberized material to absorb impacts and door dings. The front passenger’s airbag drops from the headliner, freeing up the dashboard for a deep top-hinged glovebox. With a tasty choice of colors and trim options, buyers can get the Air Bump in colors contrasting or matching the paint.

Small Commuter Car with Personality: Renault Twingo

Mercedes-Benz, which in the 1990s teamed up with Swatch on the Smart project, has been trying to make the tiny city cars viable for nearly two decades. Now that Benz has teamed up with Nissan-Renault, the Smart formula is starting to click. Enter the third-generation Renault Twingo, which uses a version of the next Smart Fortwo/Forfour’s rear-engine/rear-wheel-drive platform. A choice of a 1.0-liter three-cylinder or optional 0.9-liter turbocharged three-cylinder hides under the cargo floor cover in back.

The rear seat on this four-door hatchback is tight, but there’s ample room in front. The Twingo is just 141.3 inches long on a 98-inch wheelbase, which is just 1.7 inches longer than the Fiat 500 two-door hatchback, although the wheelbase has 7.7 inches on the Italian model. As Automobile Magazine design editor Robert Cumberford put it, the third Twingo isn’t as groundbreaking as the first-generation car (which to be fair, cribbed on the Honda City Japanese domestic model of the early 1980s), but it’s far less boring and stupid than the second-generation car. The Twingo, for you Francophiles who know what it is, is back. Unfortunately, there’s no indication that Mercedes-Smart will sell anything like it in North America.

The Wagon Master is Back: Volvo Estate Concept

But is it still the safety master? Volvo showed its third concept to preview its next generation of cars, which retain front-wheel-drive layouts but with rear-wheel-drive proportions. The Estate Concept is a two-door wagon version of the Coupe Concept that stole the show at Frankfurt last September. It is designed to recall the 1800 ES two-door wagon of the 1960s, although if you picture it with four doors instead, you’ve got a pretty good idea of what Volvo’s next large wagon will look like.

The concept is full of Scandinavian design, including orange seatbelts for the two-plus-two seats, matching orange woven wool carpeting by Swedish designer Kasthall, an Orrefors/Kosta Boda crystal shift knob, and the Swedish game of kubb under the load floor, which is a transparent panel with the rules for the game printed on it. The disappointment with this car is that Volvo stuck a large tablet in the center of the dash, replacing most control knobs with touchscreen controls. Modern? Perhaps. Safe? I don’t think so.

Schreyer’s Fuel Cell Crossover: Hyundai Intrado

Bright star designer Peter Schreyer was promoted from head of Kia design to head of Hyundai and Kia design last year, and one of his first efforts is the Hyundai Intrado concept. It’s a bit wild, even for Schreyer, what with the fins protruding from the lower rear body. Orange is the new black at Geneva this year: many cars here use the color for paint, but the Intrado has a deep orange interior. Power is by a clean, compact fuel cell powerplant under the hood.

Never Has One Car Done So Much for So Few: Mercedes-Benz S-Class Coupe

Mercedes-Benz S-Class sedans don’t sell to many people beyond the one percent. Large luxury two-door coupes are far more rare than that. The new Mercedes-Benz S-Class Coupe is the brand’s most handsome car in years, even though few will see it in their garages. The lines are clean and sleek, and with its low roofline, the big coupe looks lithe parked between a couple of new S-Class sedans.

Premium Populism: BMW 2-Series Active Tourer/4-Series Gran Coupe

BMW unveiled its not-for-U.S. 2-series Active Tourer and failed to impress with this premium multipurpose vehicle, a kind of mini-minivan with no sporting pretensions beyond an optional M badge trim level. The new vehicle is based on BMW’s 1-series front-wheel-drive models, which share components with the Mini brand. It probably should be called a 1-series or maybe even a Mini. The BMW 4-series Gran Coupe is a more convincing Ultimate Driving Machine. The four-door hatchback matches the 6-series Gran Coupe's sleekness with the 5-series GT’s hatchback versatility. This one matters to you because BMW will bring it to the U.S.

Now with Less Quirkiness: Mini Clubman Concept

The Mini Clubman Concept ditches the first-generation Clubman’s rear suicide half-doors for four conventional doors while retaining the old Clubman’s barn-door rear hatch. Still, it looks too much like the kind of conventional compact wagon sold in the U.S. in the 1960s that are still common in Europe.

Style Leader Redux, Redux: Audi TT

The inherent problem with designing such a stunning breakthrough as the original Audi TT is, What do you do for an encore? And for a third? The third-generation Audi TT is a quite handsome car, and no doubt it will be a rewarding drive. Its lines are sharper and cleaner than the second generation’s, but most casual observers will have to look twice before figuring out which model it is.

Subcompact Zoom Zoom: Mazda Hazumi Concept

Mazda put the Zoom Zoom in its Hazumi concept, which previews the second-generation, 2015 Mazda 2. The new model is appreciably bigger than the first Mazda 2, which launched in North America for the 2011 model year, and gets the large grille and general design of the bigger Mazda 3 and Mazda 6 four-door models. The Hazumi also previews Mazda’s new 1.5-liter turbo-diesel four, powering the front wheels through a six-speed automatic transmission. The engine has not yet been confirmed for the U.S. market.

pageElements.text: This news is already getting the Los Angeles online news audience to react with sarcasm and negativity ("Waste of a car"; “Parts...on average, cost ten to twenty times more than domestic and Japanese auto parts”), but over here at Jean Knows Cars, it’s all smiles.

Thanks to the generous donation of Nathalie and Travis Marg of Los Angeles telecommunications company Light Source 1, the Los Angeles Police Department has the use of the Margs' Lamborghini Gallardo, the one you see here.

Don’t get the idea you will see this in your rearview mirror on the 405 at rush hour (although that would be funny, it’s not quite the best use of an Italian supercar). Nor will it be stopping Justin Bieber, Lindsay Lohan, and their ilk. Instead, the Gallardo will be used by the LAPD's Air Support Team at charity events.
If you’re anywhere in the area this weekend, you can go see it at the Los Angeles County Air Show March 21 and 22.

If not, well, that’s what social media is good for. Visit the website, the Facebook page, the Instagram account, or the Twitter feed. According to the latter, the LAPD color scheme is a wrap applied by Galpin Auto Sports.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Matt DeLorenzo convinced me otherwise, and I moved to Detroit in 1996 to work for AutoWeek. Four years later, Jack Keebler lured me to Motor Trend, where I wrote news and rumors about future cars, voted in a dozen (each) Car of the Year and Sport/Utility of the Year competitions, and blogged as the Motor City Blogman. Detroit is to the global auto industry what Washington is to national politics. It’s easily more fascinating and as frustrating to cover as a journalist. The commute is far more interesting.

My years at Motor Trend, working side-by-side with Technical Director Frank Markus, have been enormously fulfilling. I’ve become fully immersed in the nuts and bolts of cars, and the industry. You have to keep a love for cars and driving in perspective. For me, Donna, our two collies, and my family back in Wisconsin come first. I can be nearly as passionate about politics, movies and art, and the Green Bay Packers, of which I’m a shareholder. My favorite sport is still Formula 1, though.

Automobile is about living with cars, both the good ones and the bad ones, but most importantly, the most interesting ones. With autonomous cars on the near horizon, we face the greatest threat to our enthusiasm since the malaise and oil embargoes of the ‘70s, the era when I earned my driver’s license. With Jean, Joe and their crew, Automobile already has the best, most interesting writers to explain why you should put down that mobile phone and grab the steering wheel. I’m thrilled to become part of this team and I look forward to helping place the cars and the way we drive them in context.

pageElements.text: You may remember “Mister K” and his “dogs love trucks” commercials for the Nissan Frontier pickup some sixteen years ago. Proving that Nissan loves dogs, its North American public relations department has teamed up with a Detroit organization that delivers dog food and advocates for better treatment of pets in the city’s neediest neighborhoods.

Dog Aide Community Awareness delivers food to dog owners who can’t afford it. When they deliver the food, the group’s co-founders, Jen and Beth, or their volunteers offer free spaying and neutering services and help set up routine veterinary care and rescue outreach. It's all part of an effort to improve living conditions for the pets.

Although the organization has been around for a couple of years, the issue of pet well-being has made headlines, with news reports estimating as many as 50,000 loose dogs roaming the city of Detroit. The actual number is much lower than that: anywhere from 7,500 dogs to a low-five-figure number, according to more rational estimates.

In March, Nissan North America’s public relations department invited auto journalists to ride along with Jen and Beth as they delivered bags of Blue Buffalo natural  dog food to needy families in Detroit. My wife, Donna, and I joined Jen and Beth and visited seven households, delivering high-quality Blue Buffalo natural dog food and checking up on the pets. A man who lives across the street from a park where many unwanted pets are dropped off offered to volunteer himself.

Dog Aide is doing good work. It partners with other volunteer groups to do the kind of work the bankrupt city’s animal control department can’t perform. Nissan has also partnered with The Devoted Barn, which rehabilitates a variety of neglected animals and shares the animals with at-risk youth in Southeast Detroit.

pageElements.text: Growing up in Connecticut as a talented equestrian and polo player, Lore Smith would gallop her horse as fast as she could.  “That’s why I like to race cars.  I see a connection there,” she says.

"How fast can your car go?" I ask her as we soar and roar, though at a legal speed and in great comfort, along beachside Ocean Drive from Palm Beach to Lake Worth, Florida. “It can go 220. I’ve driven at 180,” she replies with just a hint of speedster pride. “I was at a track in Sebring [the International Raceway in Florida], which has a lot of S curves, and you can see my car has paddle shifters so you can put it in auto for driving around or you can put it in manual to go on the track. I went 180 on that track, and that was a lot of fun!”

Lore’s car is astonishingly beautiful.  It is a Ferrari after all, a 2010 Ferrari California in Blu Pozzi, an elegant navy blue, with a luxurious camel-colored leather-lined interior and blue seatbelts and carpets. “I wanted to keep it understated,” she says with a laugh, as if a Ferrari could ever be understated.

Lore, a Palm Beach star real estate broker, is wearing rust suede Ferrari shoes with silver bows and carrying a Ferrari-made note pad: brand loyalty to the max. She demonstrates how to operate the quiet folding convertible hard top, which opens or closes in a mere fifteen seconds. ”A pretty good piece of engineering,” she notes.
She ordered the rear portion of her cabin as a plush luggage shelf rather than install the standard (that is, standard for a Ferrari California) two smallish additional seats.

I ask her how she shows her clients their future homes in a two-seater. “That’s the ten-million-dollar question,” she replies. “Or maybe it’s the 100-million-dollar question. Basically, I work with clients who are hedge manager types of people. It’s generally the men who look at the houses, and when they see something they want to invest in, they bring their wives and then meet me at the property. My husband has a Jaguar, which seats four comfortably. I find in real estate, nobody gives me any grief with this car.”
Are people ever surprised to see a woman driving a Ferrari?  “Yes.  I like that.  The surprise element.”

Are people ever surprised to see a woman driving a Ferrari? “Yes. I like that. The surprise element.” Lore, who handles luxury residential property transactions for Sotheby’s International in Palm Beach, has been cited on a list of the top 250 agents in the United States by the Wall Street Journal. She had originally been a second-grade teacher, but “I wanted longer vacations and longer lunch hours.” And she found she was "pretty good at selling real estate.”

Lore admits her Italian import was an impulse buy.  “Life is very short, and you might as well enjoy every second of it…I’ve always been a car person.“ Each year, the fabled Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach hosts the Cavallino Classic Concorso d’Eleganza, where hundreds of Ferraris and their owners line up on the manicured lawn to celebrate the formidable vehicles. It was at one such parade of cars that Lore fell for the California.  And now, since becoming a Ferrari owner, she is a participant in the five-day event every January in which various classic and exotic cars and car enthusiasts form a procession through nearby towns, take jaunts around a local raceway, join a Jet Reception at the Palm Beach Airport, and participate in further celebrations at Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago Club.

Prior to the Ferrari, Lore drove a Bentley Continental GTC. “I found the Bentley too heavy as an automobile, too hard to maneuver around.” Instead, the aluminum Ferrari feels light and frisky and sexy and agile. She has encountered no mechanical problems with her car, other than needing a single adjustment of the fluid for the retractable hard top. The 2010 California was the first Ferrari to have a seven-speed dual-clutch automated manual transmission. This front-engine, rear-wheel-drive car is powered by a 4.3-liter V-8 with 460 horsepower and 357 pound-feet of torque. Although not as expensive as some other Ferraris, the California’s sticker price is still in the $200,000 range. The fuel consumption is 13/19 mpg.

Lore and her husband, Tony, are passionate sailors who have chartered sailboats in such far-flung locales as Tonga, the Seychelles, Tahiti, Vietnam, Cambodia, New Caledonia, and Thailand.  I ask her to compare sailing a Ferrari to sailing around the world.  “Well, the Ferrari goes a lot faster than a sailboat!  As we’ve been traveling to Africa over the past four or five years, I would compare the Ferrari to a cheetah [like the one she's posing with here], one of the fastest animals to get from zero to sixty.“ Her Ferrari takes about four seconds.

Of our intoxicating but brief journey along the Gold Coast of Florida in Lore’s California dream car, she says, “I love this particular drive.  If I am stressed out, I pop in the car and take the top down and just drive….You can see how this can put you in an instantly happy mood.”
And of the storied marque that generates so much happiness, Lore Smith says, “The Ferrari is a work of art.”

At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Photo at top by Kevin Davies
Even if you don't realize it, you know who Philip Treacy is. He is one of the world's great milliners, the hatmaker to the Royals, the man who designed the crazy "toilet lid hat" for Princess Beatrice to wear to the royal wedding in 2011, the man whose outrageously beautiful works of art adorn the heads of aristocrats and fashion's most daring worldwide. (Even my head, as you'll see in this video.)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/b0rQ3kaUs8U?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

My visit to London this winter could not have gone without a pilgrimage to Treacy's atelier. The conversation turned to his muse, the one-of-a-kind Isabella Blow. Born into the British aristocracy, Isabella transcended its staidness and created a new way of looking at fashion and style. She was disowned by her father and forced to make her own way at an early age. Starting as assistant to Anna Wintour at Vogue, she took center stage in the British fashion world, where she discovered designer Alexander McQueen—and Philip Treacy, whom she hired to design hats for her wedding while he was still a student. She forced Alexander McQueen, who was quite a wild child, onto the fashion scene, to the horror of the tightly knit fashion community, and she underlined his importance by taking the unheard-of step of buying his entire first collection herself.

Isabella Blow was a daring, tortured woman whose sense of style continues to inform Philip Treacy's work to this day. She was the subject of a retrospective exhibition of her vast collection of Philip Treacy hats and Alexander McQueen couture, Isabella Blow: Fashion Galore! which I walked through with Philip Treacy's partner, Stefan Bartlett.

Alexander, Philip, and Isabella were an inseparable trio for years. Sadly, Isabella committed suicide in 2007, aged only forty-eight. Her suicide is widely believed to have sent Alexander McQueen into a tailspin from which he never recovered, and three years later, shortly after his mother died, he took his own life.

It was a rare privilege to talk to Philip in the heart of his work space about Isabella, about his life as the most celebrated milliner in the world today,  and about where he continues to find his inspiration after all these years.

pageElements.text:
Last week I packed my bag for South Carolina. I had been invited by Michelin to come as their guest for a visit to the proving ground outside Greenville in order to learn firsthand about the company's new tire breakthrough, the Premier A/S all-season tire with EverGrip.

The event was for women in the media, some from automotive publications but mostly from female-oriented magazines, websites, and blogs. I was thrilled to abandon the frigid Michigan winter for some southern warmth. So, when I arrived on a Monday afternoon to the Greenville Spartanburg airport, a lovely little transportation hub nestled into a wooded landscape, the unseasonably cold 50 degrees felt like mid-July to this northerner.

The French tire company’s presence is deeply felt in this area. On the drive in from the airport, I already spied its North American headquarters just off the highway. Michelin established itself in South Carolina in the 1970s, taking advantage of the skilled workforce that was being displaced by the disappearing textile industry. The company now has nine plants in the state, so it’s not surprising that on my walk around Greenville's well-executed downtown revitalization along the Reedy River, I stumbled upon Michelin on Main, a retail specialty store devoted to selling clothing and other collectibles with the store’s world-famous logo.

Alas, the store closes early on Mondays.  I could only press my face to the glass, survey the goods from the outside, and gaze at the life-size statue of the Michelin Man within. Did you know he’s one of the world’s oldest trademarks and he has a name? It’s Bibendum, or “Bib” for short, and it means, “Now is the time to drink.”  (That comes from an original ad, in which he "drank" road obstacles such as nails and metal parts.) Hmmm.  Luckily, Michelin had already sent me a stuffed Build-A-Bear version of Bib, so I didn’t feel cheated by the closed doors and pressed on to see what else I could find in Greenville.

At Falls Park I came upon a stunning suspension bridge that curved out over the dropping hillside.  It was glorious to see swaths of purple impatiens and pink blossoming trees as I climbed back up to the search Greenville’s West End shops, only to find them mostly shuttered.  And then I saw it.  Perched on the edge of the ravine was Pedal Chic, a charming girl-centric bike shop with bistro tables on the outside and mint green Bianchi bikes on the inside.

It took only a few minutes for me to select a pink Pedal Chic saddlebag for my daughter and discover the manager, Lisa Parks, and I are both from the Detroit suburb of Birmingham, Michigan.  As we chatted about the charm of Greenville, the joy of biking, and what a small world it really is, in came a couple of men in serious bike gear, one needing a quick wheel adjustment.  The bike mechanic was gone, Pedal Chic was closing, but Lisa let him use the tools.

Turns out the man in need was Lee Willard, the Michelin engineer who designed the revolutionary “run flat” tire. Later on I found out he has also been a pivotal force in the Chevrolet Corvette's tire design. Naturally, he knows Jean. Lee told me that Greenville is more than just a one-company town: besides Michelin and BMW, Greenville is becoming a magnet for European investment, so you never know what kind of accent you might run across. Lee and his friend were headed out biking on the Swamp Rabbit Trail, part of his training regime for the upcoming 24 Hours of Le Mans. I wished them good riding and took off for my dinner at The Loft at Soby’s. Lee gave me a wave and a parting message for Jean. “Tell her to come to Le Mans!” If she doesn’t want to go, hey, I’ll take that invitation.

The Michelin gathering that night was delicious and a bit surreal as Bib posed for pictures with us on the rooftop deck one minute and passed a plate of crab cakes the next. Surveying the dinner table later, I was struck with the thought that years ago, when I was a program staffer at these kinds of automotive events, I was often the only woman in the room. Now, as a mother of a ten-year-old daughter, it was encouraging to see all women reporters chatting with product marketing director Cyrille Roget, one of the few men in the room from Michelin, about the challenges of de-molding the uniquely treaded Premier A/S tire (shown here).  Or hear female voices grilling technical marketing manager Sarah Robinson on how much driving time we would get on the track.

The next morning we arrived at the rain-soaked proving ground, and Tiffane Thompson, Michelin's country operations manager, explained just what makes the Premier A/S so different. First the EverGrip rubber recipe calls for a greatly increased amount of silica to enhance grip plus the addition of sunflower oil to boost traction. Second, there’s a whole new groove, expanding rain grooves to be exact, which give the Premier A/S the ability to keep evacuating water efficiently even as it wears. And last, a bit of tire magic: emerging grooves. You don’t see them when the tire is new, but more than 150 new grooves appear along the sides of the tire surface as it wears over time. Michelin commissioned this video from The Fast Draw’s Mitch Butler to lay out the tire’s new features. The result of all this cutting edge technology? Better stopping power in the wet weather and more bite in snowy conditions even as the tire clocks the miles.
It's tire magic: emerging grooves. You don’t see them when the tire is new, but more than 150 new grooves appear along the sides of the tire surface over time.

We would need stopping power since dark clouds rolled in again that afternoon, and even some hail graced the asphalt during our safety exercises, which I'll be detailing in an article to come. The main event was our chance to see what the Michelin engineers mean when they say the Premier is “safe when worn” by participating in a stopping distance comparison.  By turns, we got to drive three Cadillac CTS sedans: one equipped with new Bridgestone Turanza Serenity Plus tires; one with new Goodyear Assurance Triple Tread A/S tires; and one with half-worn Michelin Premier A/S tires at about 5/32 of an inch, about half the tread depth when new. The sun finally appeared, we shed our ponchos, and we got our chance to be the test drivers.

I was paired with engineer Michelle Phillips, who gave me my instructions to get the car up to speed and then hit the cruise control, which was set to 50 mph. We drove onto a wet patch of road, and I hit the brakes hard at a tall orange cone. The car was wired to register how far it traveled before coming to a complete stop. My first ride was on the Michelins, which stopped at 110 feet. The second time through, on the Goodyears, held up at 123 feet. My third outing was on the Bridgestones; the car fully arrested at 121 feet. I was impressed, considering the worn Michelins stopped me about a car length sooner than the others. We registered all our results on a comparison chart in the Michelin tent, and I noticed that many of my fellow participants experienced an even a more significant gap between the worn Michelins and the two competing brand-new tires, mostly in the fifteen-foot range. It was thought-provoking data.

The Michelin Premier A/S made its debut in stores on April 2.  It comes in thirty-two sizes, retails for about $156 per tire, and carries a 60,000-mile warranty. Since the new tire is designed for comfort and longer-term driving security, the initial release is geared toward sedans. Interested SUV and light-truck drivers can expect an LTX version to come out in the fall.

Eventually, it was time to leave Michelin country and my new girlfriends behind. Within two hours, I arrived back to a wind-chilled Detroit Metro Airport but warm embraces from my husband and daughter. As I recounted my experiences at the track, my husband broke in with a question. “So, what kind of tires do we have on our car?”

pageElements.text: Auto recalls are not the sexiest topic, but fewer issues are more important to your safety in the car. In 2014 alone, there were 803 vehicle recalls—the largest number in more than thirty years. Some 63.9 million vehicles were called back to fix problems. Maybe yours was one of them.
Or did you toss the recall notice as junk mail?

A lot of people do just that. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), the government agency in charge of recalls, says nearly a third of people ignore the recall notices they are sent. That’s why NHTSA came out with a new, hard-to-ignore notice label in 2014. It now adorns all envelopes sent to you about the recall, and its intent is to make sure you don't fail to spot it.
Your responsibility and privilege is to make sure you are aware of all recalls on your vehicle—or the one you are looking to buy—and get your car in for the fix.

With that in mind, here is your tool kit to make sure you are up on recalls.

1. Do a Total Recall Watch

NHTSA says that, in addition to vehicle recalls, it manages an average of 20 tire recalls and eight child seat recalls a year. That’s a lot to keep up with. The feds have a useful recall website that combines recall announcements from all its agencies. You can obsess to your heart’s content over food, medicine, cosmetics, boats, child safety seats, school buses—and vehicles, which is our topic today.

2. Subscribe to NHTSA's Email Service

NHTSA’s recall site is here. You can subscribe to be notified of all recalls for specific brand and model year (2012 Audi, for example), or get a weekly e-mail message with a summary of all vehicle recalls for the week. You can even sign up to receive e-mail alerts of tire and child safety seat recalls.

3. Read NHTSA's Owner's Manual

You can download or read NHTSA’s informative “Motor Vehicle Defects and Safety Recalls: What Every Vehicle Owner Should Know,” which explains in detail about what kinds of defects trigger a recall, how to manage one on your car, and even how to report a safety issue directly to NHTSA.

4. Do a Safety Watch from Your Phone

If you want to do it all from your smartphone, get the safercar.gov iOS app or the Android app for recall notifications and safety alerts. You can also just dial the phone to NHTSA’s Hotline, toll free, at 888-327-4236 or 800-424-9393.

5. Search for Your Specific Car

Prefer to cut to the chase? Here is where you can search your vehicle’s specific make, model, and year and find out what recalls (if any) apply to it. I tried it on my own (nearly new) car and found, thankfully, no recalls, but I got to peruse nine complaints, all minor, filed by other owners and read all the details of the problems they reported, from funny-smelling carpet to radios that didn’t work right. (Make your own complaint here.)

6. Check In on Your Brand's Owner Site

This is important because it’s always possible your vehicle can miss being logged in to the NHTSA database or be delayed. So keep in touch with the "owner" website for your car, which generally has a place to enter your car's VIN and see any recall information for that specific vehicle.
And don’t forget, when you buy a used car, you need to check its history and check for recalls, too.

pageElements.text:
Jean Knows Cars shares a building (not to mention an editor in chief) with Automobile Magazine, and, in addition to the mental stimulation of working together, we enjoy our proximity to the luscious test fleet of cars that are always close by. Automobile Magazine is temporarily without a motor gopher on staff: the person whose job it is to keep those cars clean inside and out. So they took advantage of a bright spring day to make the cleaning into a group event. I took advantage of having thirteen of them all in one place at one time and asked them for their favorite car-care tips. And here they are.

Photos by Scott Allen
Jen Misaros (Managing Editor, Digital Platforms) (vacuuming): I swear I just sucked up toenails. Gross.
My tip is, if the inside of a vehicle is really dirty, use a leaf blower. Open the doors on both sides, and blow it out. It saves you tons of time.

Rusty Blackwell (Copy Editor): Use a separate sponge to wash the wheels from the one you use to wash the painted surfaces. Wheels have all kinds of crap, brake dust, dirt, that you don't want scratching your paint. At home, when I buy a new sponge, the old one gets demoted to wheel washing.

Avoid washing a car in full sun, or you'll get water marks. And certainly never wax in full sunlight. The wax will bake on and won't come off as easily. And don't wash a car on a dirt driveway—you'll soon have mud that'll splash up and get the lower parts of the car all dirty.
Amy Skogstrom (Managing Editor): I have a chamois mitten that I use at home instead of a sponge. It gives me better control.

Joseph Capparella (Associate Web Editor): I use Q-Tips to clean out the smaller nooks and crannies in a car. I went a little crazy with the cleaning when my dad gave me his old Honda Fit. He hadn't treated it that carefully and I spent half a day getting it perfect.

Joseph DeMatio (Deputy Editor): My poor man's carpet cleaning system is to remove the paper filter from a Shop-Vac, clean all the dirt out of it, and then soak the carpeting and vacuum up the water using the Shop-Vac.
Eric Weiner (Associate Web Editor): I use a stiff-haired brush right alongside a vacuum to gather loose stuff in the carpet and vents and vacuum it up immediately.
Jake Holmes (Associate Web Editor): Pull the rubber liners out of cup holders and cubbies and clean them separately. The soap and water will pool up when you try to wash them in place.

Another simple thing I do is to clean the windshield wipers. Run a towel over the wiper blade itself, and you'll see a trail of dirt come off. Then wipe away at the glass where the wiper rests when it's stationary. That will keep the wipers working better for longer, and it reduces streaking or juddering.
Sandon Voelker (Videographer): If it's kind of cold out, fill your bucket with warm water. You'll function better when your hands aren't numb.

Thomas Hang (Graphic Designer): A lot of people tend to throw things into the back seat and leave them there. Clear out the back every day. It's a good habit to get into. I keep my car cleaned out as I go, and I rarely have to do a major cleaning.

Chris Nelson (Road Test Editor): Preventive is the way to go. The reality is that your car will only get dirty if you let it. Of course, if I kept to that at home, I wouldn't have to spend Sundays cleaning out my condo. If you keep it clean, it's easier to see when it gets trashed and takes only a small amount of time to clean.

David Zenlea (Associate Editor): Don't fill the bucket up all the way. That just wastes water and dilutes the soap. Instead, fill about halfway. If the car is really big and/or really dirty, consider emptying and refilling the bucket partway through.

When you rinse off the soap, consider removing the hose nozzle. The straight stream of water removes the soap much more effectively and without as much overspray. It's then easier to dry (it's exactly the same as when you rinse dishes in the sink).
Jackie Guenther (Executive Assistant): Go to an automatic car wash! That's my tip.
That, and get some high-quality floor mats like the WeatherTech custom-fit mats in this car. Your car automatically looks and feels much cleaner.
Todd Lassa (Executive Editor): My first tip is, marry someone who likes small cars (Mazda 2 and Miata, for example), so you have less sheetmetal to wash.

More seriously, I always use a liquid car wash soap. My father believed it stripped off the wax, but I'm sure it does the opposite, which is to protect the wax. Waxing is best twice a year, at the beginning of spring, when it's rainy, and early fall. A good wax job assures that water beads and snow/ice slide off the sheetmetal more easily.

Also, be sure to open the doors and clean out the inside of the rocker panels and the doorjambs with a wet cloth. Too many people clean the exterior sheetmetal and the seats, while skipping this part, so when you open the doors, you have this line of dirt between the two.
I'm just glad I don't have to clean whitewalls anymore.

pageElements.text: Every day, drivers like you and me read signage successfully and exercise good judgment on the roads. So why are so many of us freaking out when we approach one of the multitude of roundabouts popping up all over the U.S.?

The roundabout is a smart traffic-calming method, generally involving a single island surrounded by two or more lanes of one-way traffic going counterclockwise. Without traffic lights, it’s up to drivers to find the right time to enter and exit in relation to the rest of the traffic.

Maybe you’ve had no trouble, so far, driving around a roundabout, yet you may still be harboring some resentment for this change in your driving world. Why do we need roundabouts anyway? According to the Michigan Department of Transportation, roundabouts are safer. They reduce speeds as well as potential “conflict points,” making crashes less severe. No traffic signals means about $5,000 a year less in maintenance costs for a single roundabout, as well as what many view as a more attractive and less cluttered road landscape. Perhaps most important, they keep cars moving, which translates to less time stuck at busy intersections.

As foreign as it seems, a roundabout is simply a different kind of intersection. Any circular anxiety you’re feeling can be remedied when you remember a few simple rules of roundabout etiquette: prepare, be aware, and calmly get out of there.

1. Prepare. Slow down as you get close to the roundabout. There’s a lot to look at: signs, lane markers, curved arrows. Determine the correct lane for your destination.
2. Yield before you go. Watch for pedestrians and bicycles, and figure out which lane you need to be in ahead of time.
3. Be aware. Look at what the traffic already in the circle is doing. Understand how close vehicles are to other entry points, and prepare to enter the roundabout when there is a gap in the traffic.
4. Get out of there. Stay in your lane, and don’t stop. Signal, then exit by peeling off and out of the roundabout to the right. If you miss your chance to exit, go around the circle again. Don’t ever change lanes, and don’t stop while you’re in the circle.

pageElements.text: Car manufacturers today have learned that they have to sell a car, not just to one person, but to an entire family. And that includes the family pet. Those of us who share our lives with pets know that their needs are an essential part of every car-buying decision. That explains why Subaru offers a Dog Matchmaker on its Facebook page, and why you’ll see dogs co-starring in ads from Land Rover and Chevrolet, among others.

Jean has been taking her four dogs along in a wide variety of test cars for years. She notes that "Cars today are so much more dog-friendly: from technology such as air bags and traction control that make cars safer than ever, to seats that fold easily so you can fit dog crates in back. That, and the proliferation of tall wagons and SUVs, means you are much less limited in your car choices as a pet owner than in the past."

At the New York International Auto Show, which will be open to the public from April 18-27, you’ll see a wide variety of cars, from dreamy supercars to the latest high-tech concepts. But what is there for someone who has an animal companion along for the ride? Good news: Here are six great possibilities, each of which will make a splashy debut at media previews in New York this week. They run the gamut from a pair of subcompacts that have surprisingly usable space in back to a couple of SUVs that will take you and your dog just about anywhere you can dream of. One might be just right for you and your pets.

1. 2015 Honda Fit Crossover

Believe it or not, this all-new version of the subcompact is enough car to let you bring your pets wherever you’re going. The hatchback, shown here, went on sale on April 14. At the New York International Auto Show, a small-SUV version, out this fall, is making its debut. Both will be built at a dedicated new plant in Mexico. Interior space was the goal, and they met it: “Man maximum, machine minimum” was the watchword in creating the completely new 2015 Fit, according to Jeff Conrad, senior vice-president and general manager of Honda Division, but “man’s best friend maximum” also applies. Conrad calls it Honda’s “packaging magic.”

Your dog gets maximum space in the back seat: even in a crate once you fold the 60/40 split seats. With both folded--which can be done instantly by flicking a switch--you get a surprising 52.7 cubic feet of space back there, easily accessed through the easy-open hatchback. If you need a subcompact but also need your pet to ride along, one of these Fits might fit your needs perfectly.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
2. 2015 Jeep Renegade

If rough and ready is what you’re looking for, the new Renegade Trailhawk will offer it in spades. It seats five—"comfortably,” promises Jeep—and you won’t feel hemmed in thanks to an optional My Sky dual-panel sunroof that can be removed and stored flat in the rear cargo area. Jeep’s Active Drive Low 4x4 system, skid plates, off-road wheels and tires, and red tow hooks complete the rugged package. “It has a good mix of being playful, but with real capable, serious bones” is how its designers, Ian Hedge and Jeremy Glover, described it. “Like a dog—just shaking it off.”

The Renegade made its debut at the Geneva Auto Show in March, is being built by Jeep’s corporate owners in Italy, and will export its all-American looks all over the world. New York marks its U.S. introduction. It will be on sale here in late 2014.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
3. 2015 Kia Sedona

The minivan is not dead, and that’s good news if you want serious carrying space without feeling like you’re driving a giant truck around town. Kia has completely overhauled its Sedona, which it wants you to call a “multipurpose vehicle.” You’ll call it gorgeous when you look inside. Available to seat seven or eight, its measurements are little changed on the outside from the old model, but it has much greater versatility, especially in the flex seating that will let you accommodate pets way more easily. Slide-n-Stow tracked seating can slide or fold upright; no middle seats to remove if you need them out of your way quickly.

Even better, you can slide the second row of seats back, first class airline style, and riders can enjoy retractable leg rests. Meanwhile, the third row is 60/40 split folding and retractable, so your passengers can ride in executive comfort, while pets and their crates have ample room in the back. Don’t be fooled by the luxurious-looking fabric; it’s antimicrobial, anti-static, and stain-repelling due to YES Essentials fabric technology. That's a first in the segment, says Kia.

We applaud the spread of the easy-open tailgate onto the marketplace, and the Sedona’s Smart Tailgate automatically opens when the key fob hovers nearby for three seconds. It’s even programmable by your height preference. And there are so many other creature comforts, such as a high-power USB charging port, a dual glove box with a cooled lower half, and a real-time Surround View camera. All this usability comes with no looks penalty, thanks to the continued design leadership of Kia design chief Peter Schreyer. It goes on sale later this year, with pricing to be announced closer to launch.

4. Land Rover Discovery Vision Concept

This is strictly a “future vision,” but pet and nature lovers of all kinds should keep an eye on Land Rover’s premium SUV ideas, even if only out of curiosity. These high-end explorers are rugged enough for your pets and more than luxurious enough for you. The Discovery Vision concept previews a future family of Discovery vehicles, plus a future set of technology that boggles the mind.

Chief among those: a set of cameras under the grille that create what Land Rover calls “an augmented reality view of the terrain.” In plain English, that means you can see what’s below the front end of your car and avoid obstacles you’ve never been able to see before. The animal lover in us applauds that extra bit of safety.

Other nice touches: a one-piece, power-operated tailgate; a deployable rear sill step and a folding bench seat in the loading area in back; and washable, oil-repellent Foglizzo premium leather that, Land Rover promises, "can be cleaned in seconds." That, and the Harris Tweed accessory trim, is the kind of thing you buy a Land Rover for.

pageElements.text:
5. 2015 Subaru Outback

If you know anything about dogs and cars, you already know that Subaru wants to be the dog lover’s brand of choice. Although the official unveiling isn’t until Thursday, April 17, teaser images released ahead of time show that the 2015 Outback will have similar breedlines to the five generations of Outbacks that came before. That means a tall-wagon look, more ground clearance than most wagons, plus Subaru’s expected all-wheel drive to make it a go-anywhere, do-anything, take-your-dog-with-you vehicle. Both 2.5-liter four-cylinder and 3.6-liter six-cylinder engine choices in Subaru's traditional horizontally opposed, or "boxer," configuration, are expected to be offered, along with improved, more luxurious interiors—but Subaru practicality is sure to be an important part of the package. Another good alternative for dog owners from Subaru: the 2015 Legacy, which was introduced earlier this year.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
6. Volkswagen Golf SportWagen

There are lots of Volkswagen cultists, and they have a point. Jean showed how well her Jetta SportWagen works for her family and its four dogs in our video review. At the New York show, VW will show a concept SportWagen that previews the model slated to go on sale several months from now, in early 2015.

If you have dogs to bring along in your car, VW’s SportWagens let you think 
outside the box and have the sleeker, lower wagon experience without losing SUV-like practicality. As part of a clean redesign, the Golf SportWagen has a lowered height at the tailgate and a wide rear window, and that means better load-in for you and your dogs. The Golf SportWagen is a preview of a larger, yet more fuel-efficient VW to replace that Jetta. It has a new TDI Clean Diesel or a 1.8-liter turbocharged gasoline engine.
This concept has a trifecta of desirable attributes: all-wheel drive, up to 17 percent better fuel economy, and, VW says, as much cargo space as a compact SUV.

pageElements.text: There's nothing quite as essential as a child safety seat in the car: required by law, for one thing, and an absolutely indispensable piece of safety equipment to protect your child, for another. But wrestling it in and out of the car, let alone lugging it through the airport or into a rental car or taxi, is one of parenting's greater annoyances.

Leave it to Volvo to come up with a solution: this new inflatable child seat concept. It's a rear-facing seat that is strong enough to do all that a safety seat needs to do, without the cumbersome qualities you've been used to. It's rear facing and can accommodate children up to four years old.
You won't be surprised to hear that the seat concept's designer, Lawrence Abele, has two children. He's design manager at the Volvo Monitoring and Concept Center in Los Angeles.

It inflates in a stunning forty seconds, using an integrated pump, and weighs a mere eleven pounds. When deflated, it stores in a handy bag (as shown here). Compare that with your average seat, for example the Britax Marathon rear-facing convertible seat, which weighs in at a hefty 19.5 pounds and, despite its excellent safety qualities, has no shape-shifting properties.

The light weight and inflatability are due to the use of a "drop-stitch fabric" material developed for use in boating. Volvo's  Maria Hansson notes that the military has also used it in trying to make (wait for it) inflatable airplanes. It also was designed for Swedish-style good looks with some stylish liner fabrics, as shown here.

I have child-seat-lugging memories of my own, so I applaud this concept, which can't hit production too soon. No surprise that it comes from the automaker that created the world's first rear-facing child safety seat...this one, in 1964.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
“Here lies one whose name was writ in water.”

Epitaph on the tombstone of Keats

Sandra Lou Jennings, Chesapeake Bay retriever of my heart for the past fourteen-plus years, has departed this mortal coil after a full and glorious life of hunting, swimming, and being queen bee of the Jennings dog pack.

My husband, Tim, and I brought Louie home to be a companion for our first Chessie, the mighty Ron Dog. They were fast friends, and she joined him in our fields and streams once we sorted out her poor little back legs. A genetic defect caused both rear knees to require a complete rebuild before she was one year old, a surgery that she patiently endured but that just undid Tim. He called me on the way back from the vet with a frantic message that I had to hurry home from work because she was distraught. I arrived in a rush to find Lou dozing, but a very distraught husband.

She also had a lower jaw that never fully grew out, leaving her with the overbite of Marge Simpson, necessitating the removal of her upper canines so the lower teeth wouldn’t impact the roof of her mouth.

None of this impacted her hunting skills, however. She unfailingly retrieved any downed bird she’d flushed and carried it proudly and unerringly to Tim’s or my hand, with her big, old fluffy tail flailing briskly as she walked up. Her first retrieve was in the duck marshes around Delacroix, Louisiana, when I shot a duck that cartwheeled through the air at a zillion miles an hour; slammed into Tim’s chest, nearly knocking him on his ass; and fell dead on the ground in front of little one-year-old Louie’s sleeping nose. She woke up, sniffed, stood up, picked it up, and put it into Tim’s outstretched hand.
Never any drama, a serene presence in the pack of snippy Chessies. The best hunter, the prettiest head, the sweetest face, and the most angelic disposition.
And that’s the way it remained with her: Never any drama, a serene presence in the pack of snippy Chessies. The best hunter, the prettiest head, the sweetest face, and the most angelic disposition.
Our LouLou Belle, as the writer Susan Orlean nicknamed her during a road trip we took down south in 2000. Our Lucifer when she was nosing in the trash.

Lou remained remarkably healthy all of her life, but as she aged, those rear legs began to let her down. Our vet told us it was the legs that would finally take her out. And they did, although we slowed the decline with medicine, with lots of swimming, and then with acupuncture, which was remarkably effective.

It was such a tough, tough winter. We were hoping against hope we could limp her through and then give her the summer of her life. She made it through all three Polar Vortices, waited until I got home from my two-month TV shoot in Los Angeles, and spent a week basking in pets, brushes, all the treats she wanted, and being lifted into bed at night.
But even as her hearing remained sharp, her heart beat strong, her appetite raged, and her angelic disposition never faltered, those twisted back legs finally gave up the ghost.
Goodbye, our little bat-eared dog, our precious Lou. We will remember and love you forever.

pageElements.text: This month, Consumer Reports announced it has implemented a new car seat crash test protocol. The consumer organization believes these changes will better simulate the kind of accidents that unfortunately happen in the real world. In this new testing, the car seat being tested is secured onto a new bench made of stiffer materials that more closely mimic the average auto’s interior as well as the angle at which the car seat will likely sit. Second, the testing now incorporates a surface that approximates the back of the front seat, a common factor in frontal crash injuries. And the standard simulation speed of 30 mph for a frontal impact has been increased to 35 mph. Here's a video explanation of the new testing:

Of course, testing is important, but it loses meaning if you don’t use the appropriate seat for your child. To find the right fit for your newborn, toddler,  or elementary school kid, and to find tips for proper installation, try some of these resources.

1. Know the Kind You Need

Clear and concise explanations of the various types of child restraints (rear facing, forward facing, booster and seat belt) and how to use them are available at Parents Central from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Its car seat recommendations page is color coded and simple to understand. Also look there for a useful downloadable brochure that even has a Vehicle Safety Features chart which gets super detailed about LATCH tether locations, types of air bags, and more for every vehicle model.

Or check our earlier story, What Car Seat When?
If you prefer a video explanation of the various car seat types, a great place to visit is AAA’s Car Seat Safety: A How-to Guide.

2. Find One That's Easy to Use

Securing a squirming toddler already has its challenges without the car seat functions complicating matters. “Ease of use” takes into account factors like clarity of labels and instructions as well simplicity in making necessary adjustments or completing installation. Consult NHTSA's Ease of Use ratings for individual child seats.

3. Then, Install It Correctly

It’s worth repeating. Read the instructions thoroughly for your particular car seat before installing it in your vehicle. Additionally, visit the manufacturer’s website. Many now have detailed video demonstrations for each of their child restraint models. If you're shopping for a new car, always take the car seat with you and make sure it fits well in the back seat.

Still not sure that you’ve done it right? Safecar.gov helps you find an inspection station near you by state or zip code. Stations will have a technician available to physically install your car seat correctly and teach you how to do it yourself. We visited one and made a video; watch it here.

4. Register and Watch for Recalls

It takes a little extra time, but make sure to register your new car seat with the manufacturer so you'll receive vital safety updates or recall information. Parents Central has a “registration and recalls” page that makes it easy to go to your manufacturer’s registration page directly. Then, sign up to get automatic recall notices from NHTSA.

All the due diligence you’ll do to find the right car seat is worth it.  The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that the use of child restraints in passenger vehicles reduces the risk of death in infants by 71 percent and in toddlers by 54 percent.  Those are life-saving statistics parents can’t afford to ignore.
