contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $38,950 (including destination charge); AWD model is $40,500 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.8-liter V-6, 311 horsepower, 293 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/29 mpg highway (AWD model: 16/25 mpg)
My favorite standard feature: Hyundai BlueLink telematics system with Siri integration
Option I can’t live without: Matte wood (only available by purchasing all three option packages, $11,000)
Notable standard features on this model: Navigation system with rearview camera, lumbar support on driver's seat, height-adjustable passenger's seat with lumbar support, HD radio, Sirius XM Travel Link, proximity sensing key, push-button start
Notable options: Panoramic sunroof (part of Signature package, $4,000); lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, smart cruise control with full stop, parking assist (part of Tech package, $3,500); head-up display and CO2 sensor (part of Ultimate package, $3,500)
You might also be considering: Acura RLX, BMW 528i, Buick LaCrosse, Cadillac CTS, Lexus GS350, Lincoln MKZ, Mercedes-Benz E350

When I say Genesis, do you think of Phil Collins? Or when I say Hyundai, do you think of cheaply built cars? If you answered yes to either question, it is time to join the modern age and meet the 2015 Hyundai Genesis. At right around $40,000 and bursting with amenities, improved handling, and sophisticated styling, this second-generation Genesis is neither old nor cheaply built. Hyundai is aiming to win over current buyers of mid-size luxury cars with this sedan. The Korean automaker is also hoping the new entry will lift the brand’s status overall. The Genesis has been refined and tweaked to help achieve these goals, but I wanted to know, is it good enough to succeed?

There are three flavors offered: a 3.8-liter V-6 with rear-wheel drive—which is the one we drove—plus a 3.8-liter V-6 with all-wheel drive and the top-end, 420-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 with rear-wheel drive. All three are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The addition of the AWD V-6 may be a game changer for sales in areas of the country that shy away from rear-wheel drive.

Part of the appeal of the new Genesis will also be the plethora of standard features, including navigation with rearview camera, hill hold control, power folding outside mirrors, a twelve-way power driver’s seat with lumbar support, a power height-adjustable passenger's seat with lumbar, HD radio, Hyundai’s BlueLink telematics system, SiriusXM Travel Link, and a proximity sensing key with push-button start. The most unusual feature: when you stand behind the locked vehicle with the key in your pocket for more than three seconds, the trunk magically opens.

Our test car, the $38,950 base 3.8-liter V-6 with rear-wheel drive, did not include any options, but I checked out other Genesis models that included three option packages. Some or all of these can make the Genesis swankier and boost its safety feature count. The Signature package has blind spot detection, a panoramic roof, and power rear sunshades with manual rear-seat side shades; it costs $4,000. The next step up is the Tech package, which includes premium leather, a driver’s seat extender, lane departure warning and lane keeping assist, smart cruise control, and parking assist; it's priced at $3,500. But to get the Tech package, you also must purchase that $4,000 Signature package. And the hits keep on coming. The Ultimate package is $3,500 and includes impressive matte finish wood, a head-up display, a power trunk, and a CO2 sensor to avoid drowsiness. But you must purchase both the Signature and Tech packages as well. Ouch, we are now at $49,950. I prefer to trick out my ride one item at a time.

There are a few gems buried in these pricey packages. The panoramic roof that is currently all the rage does add glamour, and those sun shades are nice for keeping the sun off your precious cargo. The smart cruise control with full stop is also a nice feature. The CO2 sensor is interesting, but it seems like the emperor’s new clothes to me.

But my heart goes thump-thump for the matte wood available in the ultra-expensive Signature package. Bentleys and Rollers can keep their glossy wood. I like wood that actually looks like wood, and this, my friend, actually has grain you can feel. At the very least, when you are sniffing around the Hyundai dealership, check out the matte wood.

I do have a bone to pick with Hyundai about the head-up display (HUD). It is a fabulous feature that can display speed, turn-by-turn navigation, blind spot detection, smart cruise, lane departure, traffic, and collision warning. But it does not work with polarized glasses! I wear sunglasses 365 days a year, so this function would only help me at night. As a huge fan of HUDs, to say I was disappointed is an understatement.

The Genesis can hold its own in the looks department against any luxury or near-luxury competitor. It is elegant, with an expansive hood and a graceful swooping roofline. The grille is big and bold without being gaudy. I love the way the side mirrors fold when you lock the door, as if to remind you that your car is special and deserves to be protected from a careless neighbor car. The new winged badge replaces the standard Hyundai badge on the previous generation, putting the icing on the upscale modern design.
Near-luxury buyers who are looking to move up into the luxury category will be especially pleased with the cabin design.

Helping achieve the sleeker design is a gain of nearly three inches in the wheelbase but only 0.2 inch in overall length. This allows for shorter rear and front overhangs while also increasing the passenger volume to 107.7 cubic feet. Compare that with 100 cubic feet in the Lexus ES. In fact, the rear seat of the Genesis is downright spacious. Once you are in the cabin, you will forget your preconceived notion that Hyundai builds economy cars. The standard leather actually feels premium. The steering wheel is leather wrapped and sports the winged Genesis badge, and its buttons are handsome as well. The standard wood is slightly disappointing after seeing the optional matte variety, but not a deal breaker. Near-luxury buyers who are looking to move up into the luxury category will be especially pleased with the cabin design.

BlueLink apps will deliver notifications when maintenance is due, and customers can use the system to schedule service. There is even a special app for Google Glass users. And iPhone users can use Siri through their phone for voice commands. I have a love/hate relationship with Siri, but she did help me find the phone number to Target as I kept my eyes glued to rush-hour traffic.

The Ride

The driving experience has taken a giant step forward from the previous generation, but the 2015 Genesis still doesn't quite make it to the front of the luxury pack. There are three drive modes: Sport, Eco, and Normal. Suspension enhancements have improved the ride, although over our potholed asphalt it wasn’t as smooth as some of its competitors. The steering was light, but the car cornered nicely with minimal body roll. I didn't find the cabin as quiet as a luxury car's should be.

As I mentioned, Hyundai used luxury models as its benchmark, specifically the Lexus GS and ES, the Mercedes E-Class, and the Cadillac CTS, as well as the BMW 5 Series and the Audi A6. That is great news for their more likely buyers, people in the near-luxury market who are considering competitors such as the Acura RLX, Buick LaCrosse, and Lincoln MKZ. It is also a nice step up for Hyundai's Sonata and Azera owners.

The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) gave its Top Safety Pick + award to the 2015 Genesis. IIHS specifically called out the automatic emergency braking system that is part of the technology package, which initiates braking if it senses a car approaching at an unsafe speed. The 2015 Genesis has not yet been tested by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

The Verdict:

I think Hyundai is doing an excellent job of changing American buyers' perceptions, and the Genesis will bolster that climb. Journalists are aware of the new quality that Hyundai has achieved, but you as the consumer may still be working with your first impression of the brand. So let me say this: If you're a near-luxury buyer with an open mind, the 2015 Hyundai is a slam dunk. If you are a current luxury-car owner but want (or need) to downsize a little, this car could make your fall back to earth less painful. But really, all consumers should pay attention to Hyundai and give them a fresh look.
Jean Jennings: Back to work on engine smoothness, especially upon acceleration...Disconcerting and not so luxurious.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: This is one fine car to sit inside, with special mention for the extremely tasteful perforated leather seats (cushioned precisely enough) and the classy center storage bin that opens from the center, like a cereal box. It feels like a car that costs at least $10,000 more. The HyundaiLink telematics are easy to understand and use, and I love the gentle chime that sounds when you first climb into the car and the sinuous voice of the HyundaiLink woman. It's also one fine car to look at. I appreciate the sleek "Fluidic Sculpture" design very much. The driving experience was competent, although as assertive as I expected; maybe the V-8 version is more in line with what the looks of the Genesis led me to expect.

Jean Jennings: The Genesis is gorgeous inside. Yes, it has an Audi grille and a Chrysler logo, but the materials and fits and finishes inside the Genesis are unquestionably sublime and rewarding. Now. Back to work on engine smoothness, especially upon acceleration. When you press the accelerator in a smooth and linear fashion (that is, you don't just stomp on it), the engine answers with a two-step response. It hesitates, then accelerates. Disconcerting and not so luxurious.

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: No! If Your Car Isn't Going to Roll down a Hill, Don't Bother

Do you need to engage the parking brake in an automatic-transmission car on level ground? I say no, and it annoys me when other people do. I wear a helmet every time I ride a bike. I do not tailgate. I look both ways before I cross the street. But when it comes to the emergency brake in an automatic car, I throw caution to the wind and skip it on all but the steepest of inclines. In my over thirty years of driving, my car has never, ever rolled. I will admit that I have actually left a car in gear and it still did not roll. That I know was just karma from clean living.

Having spent most of my driving years sharing a fleet of vehicles with other drivers, I have been exposed to the emergency brake sycophants. In fact they get all car-slangy with their nouns—e-brake, hand brake, parking brake. Finally, I decided to get my frustration out and confront the issue head on.
In my over thirty years of driving, my car has never, ever rolled. I will admit that I have actually left a car in gear and it still did not roll.

First I explored what happens, technically speaking, when I put my car in Park. A metal pin called a transmission parking pawl stops the output shaft and drive wheels from turning. Unless that pin fails, this vehicle is going nowhere, and even if it fails it will only roll if it is on an incline. For those who say the parking brake will protect you if you forget to put the transmission in Park, I respond, What?! So the logic is that I will remember the brake, but not to put it in Park—not bloody likely. More likely I will forget both.

Laura is a big fan of the emergency brake (see below), and I often drive a vehicle immediately after her. I have started to back out of a parking spot more than a few times and thought the car was misbehaving. But then I quickly realized that it is Miss Brown that is misbehavin’. I am prepared to listen to her side of the story, but I am skeptical that thirty years of parking could be wrong.

Laura Says: Yes! I Use the Parking Brake Whenever I, You Know, Park

Molly Jean and I frequently take turns driving test cars, and I have grown used to her complaints that she has to take three seconds to release the parking brake after I've been in a car. To which I respond: Tough luck. That's three seconds of her life she is not getting back. Why? Because I am one of those people who take the parking brake's name to be its job description, and I generally engage the brake when I park any car.

Is this a stupid idea? I know, my car is almost never going to roll away if I don't. I guess it started for me because I owned a manual-transmission car for several years, and I know nearly everyone parks one of those with the car in gear and the parking brake set. If you don't, there's a chance it will slip out of gear, and then nothing is holding it in place. But an automatic?
Yes, I say, even an automatic, because the car is equipped with that brake in the intention of having you use it. I did some research to see if my instinct is correct. Here's what I found.
I know owner's manuals tell you to do a lot of things, but what's the big deal about also doing this? I ask you.

I checked the owner's manuals for a random sample of cars: the 2014 Ford Fusion, Toyota RAV4, Porsche Panamera, and Mazda MX-5 Miata. All of them instructed that the parking brake should be set whenever you park, even on automatic-transmission models. Yes, I know owner's manuals tell you to do a lot of things, but what's the big deal about also doing this? I ask you.

Does it do any good? According to Paul Seredynski, Ford's manager of global powertrain technology communications, using the parking brake regularly "keeps the components from crusting up and often maintains the cable's lubrication." He uses his! I'm glad to join him. I know I want my car's components un-crusty.

He even has a ritualized sequence, which he credits to having learned from a colleague at Land Rover: "It's all about removing transmission loading: stop, allow vehicle to settle, apply [parking] brake
firmly, allow to settle, place transmission in Park." Good enough for me.
And you? Molly and I are both very interested to see who's on our side. Let us know.

pageElements.text: Jean is still waiting for the perfect car-inspired millinery, and that desire has grown since she saw the cunning link between cars and fashion drawn by Prada’s 2012 spring/summer collection.

The Italian fashion house showed off purses emblazoned with cars, stiletto heels with flames borrowed from hot-rod graphics, and nursery-style car prints on blouses, skirts, and scarves. All of these have been copied widely.

pageElements.title: Prada's car-inspired fantasy footwear and accessories channeled the 1950s.

pageElements.text: The link between horsepower and high fashion is natural: designers are fond of saying that cars and clothing are two of the most revealing things about a person. Cars are considered to be basically another layer of clothing when you go out into the world, and that's all the more true in visually oriented and status-obsessed places like Los Angeles.

Automakers continue to be hip to this connection, frequently hooking up with fashion designers to put a special spin on their vehicles. Witness the Fiat 500 Gucci model, which sells for $24,200 and borrows the iconic Gucci stripe for the car’s exterior trim and seatbelt straps. Even expensive supercars like the Lamborghini Murciélago have received the haute couture treatment. Versace put its hand to the Murciélago in the past, adding such details as the fashion house’s signature Greek key motif on the lower doors and front fascia, as well as a hand embroidered motif on the black-and-white leather seats. And let us not forget Bugatti's $2-million-plus Bugatti Veyron Fbg by Hermès—featuring extensive use of bull calfskin inside and out—at the 2008 Geneva Auto Show.

pageElements.title: Fiat 500 by Gucci: The designer name added even more Italian chic to the little car.

pageElements.text: It’s not unusual for car designers to come out of the fashion industry either. Ford’s Anthony Prozzi, a senior interior designer, began his design career in fashion as a designer at Donna Karan.
“The thought that goes into designing a new vehicle is extensive,” Prozzi says. “And it’s very similar in many ways to the creative process fashion designers follow when they’re creating clothing.”
The road runs in both directions. Joe Ponce, a former designer at Ford and General Motors, switched his focus to footwear and now designs high-end shoes for Gwen Stefani’s L.A.M.B. label.

pageElements.text: The 2013 MDX – no changes from last year’s model – is Acura’s bestselling SUV for a reason. It seats seven, can tow up to 5,000 pounds, and has more cargo space than any other car in Acura’s lineup. It also handles like a much smaller car, with Acura’s impressive all-wheel-drive system to help it around corners. The MDX’s 3.7-liter V-6 engine gives it plenty of power, and a new six-speed automatic transmission helps it achieve 21 mpg on the highway and 16 mpg in the city, so it's more fuel-efficient than previous models. The MDX’s interior isn’t quite cutting edge, but it does handle the task of making a seven-seater feel spacious and comfortable.  With spacious front seats, a reclining second row, and an available rear video monitor, the MDX could be the answer for moms who shun the minivan. This utilitarian vehicle is not for everyone, however. With a base price range topping out just above $55,000 and a taste for premium fuel, the MDX makes you pay for everything you get. pageElements.text: The 2013 Acura TSX makes no changes from the 2012 model year, but it comes with enough options to make up for it. The TSX comes as a sedan or wagon, with either a 2.4-liter 201-horsepower engine (lots of fun, even if it lacks some power) or a 3.5-liter V-6 with more brute force. Acura’s silky-smooth manual transmission is available in the sedan. The TSX compliments its punchy engine with a new, smoother suspension. The sedan has a paltry 12.6 cubic feet of trunk storage, but this car was clearly not built to move a family cross-country, and with its other features you might not miss the space. If you do need more room in the back, the wagon has twice the cargo space of the sedan. Believe it or not, a car this fun to drive doesn’t have to be a gas guzzler. At 19 to 22 mpg in the city and 28 to 31 mpg on the highway, the TSX is more efficient than Acura’s more sedate (read: boring) sedans. Its relatively low cost is reflected in the lack of a navigation system in the manual, and the more powerful V-6 comes at a premium. These small sacrifices just might be worth it for the chance to drive the TSX.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Cars that act as mobile WiFi hotspots are growing common. Audi offers the technology in all models except the A3, TT and R8. Jeep, BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Ford offer it as an option throughout their fleets. Drivers not lucky enough to have roving WiFi in place when they buy a car can buy after-market routers online (Amazon’s got them) and turn even a car on its last legs into a WiFi palace. AutoNet is a popular provider of the routers, which run $200-$400 at online retailers.

The Audi technology allows up to eight devices to connect to the hotspot, enough for each passenger to connect two devices, depending on the car. Audi claims that the connection is speedy enough to stream music to the car’s stereo.

The WiFi option is best for vehicles that often carry passengers, since drivers obviously shouldn’t surf the web from behind the wheel. But if the kids have developed a taste for Phineas and Ferb episodes streamed from the iPad, this could be a lifesaver. It should come as no surprise to us who have been bled dry by smartphone bills that the WiFi won’t work without a subscription to a data plan. New cars often come with a free trial, but once that runs out you’ll pay around $30 a month for the sweet privilege of letting other people stream video in your car.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Receiving a text message while you’re behind a wheel is like having an itch that you shouldn’t scratch. As a kind of automated--and legal--back scratcher, Honda includes an SMS voice-to-text function that can read out loud the texts you receive while you’re driving in the CR-V. Using your smartphone and CR-V Bluetooth connectivity, you’ll see alerts on the Intelligent Multi-Information Display (i-MID) or in-dash navigation screen when you receive a text message. With your steering wheel controls, you can choose to listen to the messages over the vehicle’s audio system. While you won’t be able to send a custom message, you’ll have the option to reply to the SMS with one of six pre-written responses. This clever little feature makes it possible for you to listen to text messages the second you receive them without even touching your phone. After all, not everyone has Siri. The only hard part will be finding a phone that is compatible with this technology. Only a handful of BlackBerry and Android devices have the required Message Access Profile (MAP) Bluetooth profile that supports this vehicle’s systems integrations. However, more smartphone manufacturers seem to be catching on to the need for tighter integration with vehicles.
This feature made its debut on the 2012 CR-V. The 2013 CR-V is priced at $22,695 to $30,195.

pageElements.text: Women have embraced compact crossovers like the Ford Escape and the Honda CR-V because they are flexible, fuel efficient, and the right size for most needs.

In fact, it wouldn't be too much of a stretch to say that this is the Year of the Compact Crossover, with lots of new and improved models, including the all-new 2013 Ford Escape and Mazda CX-5 and the redesigned CR-V. With gas prices climbing steadily, the fuel-efficient little performers are bound to grow in popularity.

The Escape tops out at 33 mpg on the highway with its 1.6-liter EcoBoost engine mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. It has the distinction already of being the top-selling "utility vehicle" in the United States, and the new model should win even more fans.

J.D. Power and Associates notes that women have made the compact crossover their favored body style. Honda CR-V buyers, in particular, are mainly female. The same is true for such vehicles as the Hyundai Tucson, the Volkswagen Tiguan, and the Kia Sportage.

The CR-V is also worth a look because it has been the bestselling car-based compact utility vehicle in nine of the past fifteen years. The fourth-generation model went on a major diet, losing about 50 pounds and shrinking about an inch in length. The CR-V's lighter weight and better aerodynamics improve fuel efficiency, and that's a big priority in this class. The EPA said the front-wheel-drive 2012 CR-V returned 23 mpg in city driving and 31 mpg on the highway.

Another all-new crossover that's sure to be a style leader is the 2013 Mazda CX-5. Mazda notes that, thanks to its 2.0-liter engine that makes 155 horsepower, you can get up to 26 mpg in town and 35 mpg on the highway--if you opt for the manual transmission. The automatic tops out at 32 mpg on the highway.

Anyone who's ever struggled with groceries and a baby on her hip will appreciate the Escape's hands-free power liftgate, an option on the 2013 model--you just have to kick your foot under the bumper, and up it goes. 

Another clever feature is the seat folding aid in the CR-V. Now you can avoid having to fold up the seat cushions manually before folding down the seat backs. Both operations can be done by simply pulling a lever in the cargo compartment.
You'd be hard pressed to think of another vehicle type that is more friendly for women. You might call it a multi-tasker's best friend.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. relatedArticles.title: What Car Seat When?

pageElements.text: If you’re a parent, you probably remember the strange sensation you have when you’re allowed to take your child home for the first time. There’s that little voice in your head saying, Really? You are letting me take this person home? Can I be trusted?
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/S3R6dg38V-8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It’s good to know that on one issue, at least—your child’s car seat—there actually is a village to help you. Both the Safe Kids organization and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) run events around the country to help you install your child seat absolutely correctly. The trained experts you’ll find there come armed with the latest rules and information, not only about installation but about what kind of seat a child should have at different sizes and ages.

Jean Knows Cars paid a visit to a car seat event at our local fire station in mid-September. As a veteran car seat user, I thought I knew everything about car seats. Not so! I learned that volunteer and paid car seat checkers attend an intensive thirty-two-hour course to learn how to do it right, and then they share this knowledge with the community at free events.  You can make an appointment, drive in, and have a team of experts get into your vehicle and show you how it’s done. And you should.

Our local Safe Kids effort, affiliated with the University of Michigan’s Mott Children’s Hospital, has a Buckle Up hotline that parents can call to have a car seat check while they are still at the hospital delivering their baby. Or they can get the check taken care of ahead of time. As you’ll see in the accompanying video, we met a woman being proactive and having the check while still in her third trimester of pregnancy. Another woman came with her active toddler and cheerful 18-month-old to get a pair of new seats installed. The technicians educated her that rear facing is still safest at least until age two, then off they all went, with both boys happily settling in to their new seats.

It was great to learn that low-income families who qualify can get new, safe child seats free of charge. In Michigan, the money to do this comes from a grant from the state’s Office of Highway Safety Planning.

So go ahead, doubt your parenting abilities in 100 different areas—I know I have! But go get a car seat check in your own neighborhood so you can drive off, secure in the knowledge that you’re doing that part right.

pageElements.text: Yes, it eventually happens to all cars, even the best-selling automobile the world has ever known, the Toyota Corolla. And now, it is undeniable: the Corolla is getting old. Of course, that hasn’t stopped people from buying Corollas in droves. And so with an audible sigh, we report that 2013 brings yet another mild update to a car that has been around in its current form seemingly for an eternity. So why do people still buy the Corolla en masse? Simple: it’s simple…as in uncomplicated, plain, or as some might say, dull. And to be fair, one person’s dull is another’s “reliable transportation,” and don’t expect us to argue with that. But don’t expect us to get too excited about it, either, as the only available engine remains a wimpy 132-horsepower 1.8-liter four-cylinder mated to five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions. The Corolla LE and S models receive some reconstituted option packages, and a new 6.1-inch screen-based interface for the Display Audio system. Fuel economy is respectable but falls short of newer, fresher, and far more exciting competitors such as the Ford Focus, the Chevrolet Cruze, the Volkswagen Jetta, and the Hyundai Elantra, all of which should be considered by anyone looking at a new Corolla this year.

title: 2012 Toyota Prius c
subTitle: Smaller, lighter, less powerful Prius is cheaper but not necessarily more efficient.

pageElements.text: In 2012, the Toyota Prius family quadrupled in size, adding a small wagon (Prius v), a plug-in (Prius Plug-in), and this little cutie, the Prius c. Along with Honda’s dowdy Insight, the Prius c was designed to satisfy the burgeoning demand for more affordable hybrids. Although it is hardly a thing of beauty, it is easier to look at than the regular Prius, with its more conventional profile and whimsical color palette. Heck, we give it a pass simply for not looking “like a hybrid” (i.e., doorstop chic). We can’t give it the same kudos for the way it drives, as it is suuuh-looooow, with a total of just 99 horsepower combined between its gasoline and electric powertrains. Yawn. Worse still is that it isn’t any more fuel efficient overall than the heavier, more powerful non-c Prius, which gets the same 50 mpg combined fuel economy rating from the EPA. Like the Prius, the c model does have an EV mode, which allows parking lot cruising to be done (up to a mile at speeds up to 25 mph) purely on electricity. But again, the whole point of the Prius c is not to out-Prius the Prius but to come in at a lower price point, and that it does, some $4,000 to $5,000 less than its bigger brother Prius. Even with all the bells and whistles, which include automatic climate control, push-button starting, fancy Display audio system with touchscreen operation, power exterior mirrors, heated seats, and more, the Prius c costs barely more than the lowest grade of standard Prius. For a 50-mpg car, that’s a pretty good deal.

pageElements.text: One of the first in the current wave of folding-roof convertibles, the Volvo C70 hasn’t seen many changes since its debut in 2006, yet it remains desirable. The gracefully drawn lines give the car a timeless elegance, while the folding hard top supplies all-season practicality. (There’s even an available Climate package with heated front seats and an interior air quality system.) At the touch of a button, the top goes through its contortions in thirty seconds. With a 227-horsepower turbocharged five-cylinder engine, a reasonable amount of power is on tap, making the C70 fun to drive. A five-speed automatic is the only transmission available. The available Dynamic package adds eighteen-inch wheels, active Xenon headlamps, and a sport steering wheel with aluminum inlays. For a broad upgrade in performance and luxury, add the Inscription package, which first and foremost boosts the engine’s output to 250 horsepower. The Inscription also includes gloss black trim rather than bright pieces, black wheels, a leather-covered dashboard, and rich leather upholstery. T5, Premier Plus, and Platinum trim levels are offered. The latter adds a premium sound system. With the C70’s emphasis on safety and value, it’s no wonder the car has a loyal following, even though “Swedish convertible” used to be an oxymoron.

pageElements.text: Style and content go together in this compact SUV, which matches or beats its competitors in nearly every way. Recent sales reflect the XC60’s primacy: it’s the second-most popular model in Volvo’s lineup, and the gap between it and the S60 is closing. Sleek styling helps hugely, but the XC60 is also roomy and comfortable inside, and it’s not bad to drive, offering surprising thrust and reassuring grip. The sleekness gets an appropriate complement this year in outrageous Flamenco Red and Rebel Blue metallic, available colors that will provoke indignation in the school drop-off line. There are three models: 3.2, T6 AWD, and T6 AWD R-Design. A 240-horsepower 3.2-liter six-cylinder powers the 3.2, while the T6 has a 300-horsepower 3.0-liter turbocharged six (325 horsepower in the R-Design). All share the same six-speed automatic transmission, which now is controlled by a shift lever with illuminated drive modes.

Trim levels beyond the base models are Premier, Premier Plus, and Platinum. Compared with the base 3.2, the T6 AWD R-Design has additional standard pieces of body adornment such as scuff plates and skid plates, active Xenon headlamps, navigation, and a big-time sound system. Even without them, the R-Design’s more powerful engine would make a strong case for itself.

subTitle: This all-new sport sedan is Cadillac’s hope for a rear-wheel-drive car that lines up with the best the Germans have to offer.

pageElements.text: The ATS is an important car for Cadillac—as you probably realize if you saw any of the elaborate series of adventure-driving commercials featuring the ATS on TV this summer. Cadillac is promoting this car in grand style, aiming it at people who would otherwise be looking at German performance cars. In fact, Cadillac has had BMW’s 3-series and other German sport sedans in its sights for years. With the ATS, which it tested at Germany’s Nürburgring racetrack, among other places, it may have hit the target. What’s most interesting about the ATS? It weighs less than 3,400 pounds, pretty slim for its size. It is a traditional rear-wheel-drive sport sedan, but all-wheel drive is also available. Cadillac makes much of the car’s fifty-fifty weight balance, ultra-efficient and driver-adjustable sport suspension, Brembo brakes, and long, sleek body on a 109.3-inch wheelbase. But what you’ll notice even before you take off are the interior elements. There’s carbon fiber, wood, and metal plate trim; a wraparound instrument panel with LED lighting on the gauges; and a full palette of color schemes. You can dress it up with Bose stereo, navigation, the Cadillac User Experience information and entertainment system with eight-inch touchscreen, and performance seats with power-adjustable bolsters. Safety options are the complete package, too: intelligent brake assist, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, a rear-vision camera, and side blind zone alert, among others. But what Cadillac wants you to take most to heart is a thrilling driving experience from the 272-horsepower four-cylinder turbo engine.

pageElements.text: Chances are, if you are reading this entry, you’re not interested in the subtle nuances of the Savana’s steering feel, its styling influences, or the material composition of its lower control arms. You either care about how many seatbelts it has (up to fifteen), or how much junk you can cram in the back (a lot). Or both. And that’s cool. Full-size vans are generally little more than big, graceless transportation appliances designed not for the driver, but rather for what’s behind him or her. So who’s going to notice—or care, really—that the Savana hasn’t changed much for the last sixteen years? Probably no one, unless they know that Ford just launched its all-new, full-sized 2013 Transit van, that Nissan sells a big box called NV, or that Ram is rumored to be launching a replacement for the Dodge Sprinter, which, by the way, is still sold here by Mercedes-Benz. Compared with all of those, the Savana feels decidedly old-school, and less roomy. And while it offers a slew of engines ranging from a puny V-6 to an E85-capable gasoline V-8 to a torque-laden 6.6-liter diesel V-8, and has added park assist, a rear camera, and navigation-assisted radio options, the Savana is unremarkable and outdated.

pageElements.text: If a minivan is the automotive equivalent of mommy jeans, then the 2013 Mazda 5 is more like a pair of skinny jeans. The Mazda 5 is a small minivan with the classic minivan sliding side doors. Yet it has managed to avoid the dreaded minivan stigma. It was redesigned in 2012 and is so stylish that it won’t even matter if you carry a diaper bag in your daily life. The Mazda 5 is a surprisingly versatile vehicle that can seat up to six people in three rows. On the safety side, all passengers – even those in the rear – are protected by side curtain air bags. On the plus side, the little Japanese minivan offers nimble handling, excellent steering feel, good visibility, and a configurable interior. The second-row captain’s chairs slide, recline, and fold flat, and the third-row seats have a fifty-fifty split so they can be tipped forward to create a flat loading area. It should be noted here that there is limited cargo room in the rear with the seats up. A 157-horsepower 2.5 liter four-cylinder engine is the sole engine available. It is linked to a six-speed manual transmission or a five-speed automatic transmission. Fuel economy is so-so at 21 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway with either transmission, according to the EPA. That’s just a little better than the bigger Chrysler Town & Country minivan, which returns 17 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway and offers a lot more room.

pageElements.text: If you’re driving a DBS, you’ve earned bragging rights. The DBS is the distinguished flagship that represents the best of Aston Martin – at least it was when it first came out in 2008 and replaced the Vanquish. But now the DBS is being phased out by the Vanquish. The DBS cast the mold that both the Aston Martin DB9 and the Virage have followed and polished to pristine perfection. You’ll notice that the DBS has more nuanced looks. But is sheet metal botox worth the additional $70,000 price tag? You be the judge. If you pose this question in Hollywood and certain blocks on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the answer is a resounding yes, so you’re answer is predicated on perspective. The DBS can be ordered as a two-door coupe or in convertible form as the Volante. It qualifies as both fast and foxy, reaching from 0 to 60 mph in 4.3 seconds and topping out at 190 mph. DBS went out with a high-gloss bang, releasing The Carbon Edition model for 2012, which features ten-spoke, gloss-black wheels and a Matrix-style carbon fiber cabin that is sold in flame orange, ceramic gray, and carbon black metallic.

pageElements.text: The Audi A4 is Audi’s basic luxury sedan, and it has gained the respect of drivers with its luxurious interior and exciting performance. The A4 family also includes the sporty S4, which is very fast and offers more choices for the interior. The A4 offers a turbo engine; the S4, a supercharged V-6. A choice of front- or four-wheel drive is available on sedan models, and the four-wheel-drive models come with a choice of a manual or automatic transmission. The exterior styling is typical Audi: making a statement without making you cringe. The interior styling won’t leave you flat either, especially not if you spring for one of the enviable technology packages. New for the 2013 model year are more interior choices, such as a flat-bottom steering wheel and various new seating colors and materials. The base price range tops out just shy of $50,000. (The priciest models include an expensive-but-worth-it Bang & Olufsen sound system.) Despite possible sticker shock for first time luxury buyers, the A4 is very reasonably priced compared with competitors, and buyers give up none of the fun of driving a luxury performance automobile.

pageElements.text: The A8 is Audi’s top-of-the line sedan, and it has plenty of features to back up that title. This model year's A8s will be available in four models, including a much-hyped S8 that goes from 0 to 60 mph in a very speedy 3.9 seconds. The A8’s exterior design hasn’t changed substantially, but the previous models are so good they didn’t warrant much tinkering. The A8 has long been one of the most balanced, well-proportioned sedans on the market. It carries Audi’s all-wheel drive, and despite being one of the largest sedans in its class, it maintains decent fuel mileage in some models with a highway range falling just short of 30 mpg. The interior of the A8 is quite swanky, with leather seats, wood and aluminum trim, and available extras like Audi’s MMI Google Earth interface and a rear entertainment system. A full-leather option is also available, just in case you want to spend more money on this already very expensive vehicle. Beautiful interior aside, the A8 is really about superior engineering and unnecessary (but impressive) speed, and in that respect, it absolutely delivers.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Juke stands out from the pack with its quirky looks and fun performance. It wins points as a driver’s car, but in the end may be impractical for some families. The Juke – which has been compared to a frog in the looks department – was designed to blend the benefits of a crossover with a sports car. The Juke’s standard turbocharged 1.6-liter inline four-cylinder engine provides 188 horses and punchy acceleration. The engine is linked to either a six-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable transmission that comes with the all-wheel-drive model. A three-mode drive selector – Normal for everyday driving, Sport for a more performance feel and Eco for maximum fuel efficient – gives the driver some interesting choices. Fuel economy is decent. The Juke with the CVT returns 27 mpg in city driving and 32 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The six-speed manual transmission model returns 25 mpg in city driving and 31 mpg on the highway. Tight rear seats and a relatively small cargo hold may limit the Juke’s appeal. The printed fabrics and hard plastic trim in the cabin look a little cheap. The Juke is not for everyone, but it excels with a powerful engine, confidence-inspiring handling, and optional all-wheel drive – and there are eight models to choose from.

pageElements.text: "I’m here!" screams the Bentley Mulsanne. When you pull up in the Mulsanne, you most certainly have arrived. Hello darling, you’re driving a car that costs $300,000. The pristine and proper flagship from the British automaker is a statement unto itself. Look closely and you’ll notice aluminum front fenders. Hang on: you’ll experience the refined grumble of a sophisticated twin-turbo V-8 engine, but there is little noise that can make its way in this well constructed cabin. What you’re paying for in the Bentley is quality, detail and impeccable function.  Patience is part of the ethos of Bentley manufacturing. It takes a 170 hands-on hours to build a Bentley Mulsanne at the factory in Crewe, England. Bentley has added high-tech nuances from the get-go in the Mulsanne model, such as the eight-inch color screen and the sixty-gigabyte hard drive. Here’s where Mulsanne is besting itself with new packages and options for technological splendor. Now you can’t just park a Bentley Mulsanne anywhere, so please travel with an extra stack of $20 spots for the valets. Tipping anything less from the driver’s seat of the Bentley Mulsanne would be uncivilized.

The 2013 Tucson gets some modest upgrades, including heated front seats on the GLS FWD model, a proximity key entry with push-button start on the Limited trim, foglights, and automatic headlight control on the GLS. The JX is designed to put a major emphasis on family values, without making Mom feel like she’s driving a milk truck. The JX offers stylish design, high interior quality and plenty of room in the second row, where the seats recline and slide forward and backward. The thinking here is that there’s no need to remove a child seat to access the third row. The JX is something of a technological powerhouse as well, with options like a backup collision intervention system, an industry first. If a reversing driver doesn’t spot a car or pedestrian approaching from the side, the JX flashes a warning, then pushes back against the driver’s throttle foot and finally brakes to prevent a crash. The JX’s base price of $41,400, including a $950 destination charge, can rapidly escalate, with the addition of such items as all-wheel drive and five option packages. They include a $4,950 Premium package that includes a navigation system, Around View monitor and a thirteen-speaker Bose sound system. A Driver Assistance package adds another $2,200 to the bottom line and adds the back-up collision intervention system, intelligent cruise control, a blind spot warning system, and heated steering wheel. pageElements.text: Losing weight and quitting smoking are much easier if you have a support system, experts say. But did you ever envision a day when your Ford Fiesta or Explorer could be a key part of your personal healthcare?

Ford is one of the first automakers to develop “mobile healthcare.” In the not-too-distant future, your Ford car or truck could let you know the UV index so you could apply the right amount of sunscreen, monitor your food choices at McDonald’s or check your calendar to see whether you’ll be taking a cardio dance class that day and may need an extra puff or two on your asthma inhaler. The car could even track your symptoms following chemotherapy.

In August, Ford rolled out an Allergy Alert app that is compatible with Ford Sync's AppLink, which lets drivers check pollen levels and other allergy-aggravating climate conditions by using voice commands.

Ford has hooked up with WellDoc, one of its research partners,  to develop “healthcare on the go.” The thinking is that since many people spend a good chunk of time in their cars every day, computer systems in the car – such as Ford’s Sync – could become your wellness partner. Ford said it is targeting two groups for its initial push into health and wellness mobile solutions: people with diabetes and those with asthma and allergies.
Don’t worry, though. Although your Ford may use Sync, healthcare apps and other technology, such as the vehicle’s GPS system, to track whether you are going into McDonald’s, it won’t criticize you.

Chris Bergstrom, WellDoc’s chief strategy and commercial officer, told JKC that your car “will not say anything in a judgmental way” if you choose French fries over a salad. The car, however, can calculate how many grams of fat are in that hamburger, thus helping you to make a healthier choice.
Future auto health and wellness technology could help consumers in many areas, from diabetes management to smoking cessation.

title: Plug-In Hybrids Are Nothing to Stress About

metaTitle: Plug-In Hybrids Are Nothing to Stress About: JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Plug-In Hybrids Are Nothing to Stress About. Worried about the safety of the plug-in hybrid car style? JeanKnowsCars.com has reassurance.

pageElements.text: Consumers who are worried that the Chevrolet Volt – or similar plug-in hybrid vehicles – pose a greater risk of fire than gasoline-powered autos should be reassured.
Federal safety regulators gave the Volt an all-clear after a lengthy investigation into the risk of post-crash fires in late January.

General Motors, which builds the Volt, calls it a “transformational” vehicle because it involves technology new to the auto industry. The Volt is a plug-in hybrid which uses an electric motor, a gasoline engine and a lithium-ion battery pack to achieve a miles-per-gallon equivalent of 95 in city driving and 93 on the highway.

The Volt made headlines last year after batteries in three vehicles sparked or caught fire days or weeks after being severely damaged in crash tests. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigated Volts catching on fire and now says it did not identify a safety defect. The probe was unusual in that the incidents did not happen in real-world driving, but federal safety regulators said they put the Volt under tough scrutiny because of its “emerging technology.”
“A defect trend has not been identified at this time, and further investigation does not appear to be warranted,” said NHTSA in a statement on its Web site on January 20.

The Volt has not been recalled, although General Motors will make repairs to 14,735 Volts produced prior to December 21, 2011. The automaker will strengthen the structure of the Volt, add a sensor that detects excessive battery coolant loss and add a tamper-proof device to prevent consumers from adding coolant. GM says the changes are “intended to make a safe vehicle even safer.”
GM has maintained all along that the Volt is safe, but it took unprecedented steps to reassure the public, including buying back some of the vehicles.

Congressional investigators also looked into how federal safety regulators handled the Volt investigation. They wanted to know whether NHTSA treated GM with “kid gloves” given the Obama administration’s interest in the success of the Volt and its stated commitment to getting one million electric vehicles on the road by 2015.
GM CEO Daniel F. Akerson told Congress on January 25 that “we did not engineer the Volt to become a political punching bag and that’s what it has become.”
“I don’t think there was ever an imminent threat to any [Volt] customers,” said Akerson.

If you’re squeamish about adopting new technology in cars, the Volt is probably not for you, but federal safety regulators say the Volt and similar vehicles show great promise as a safe and fuel-efficient option for U.S. drivers.

pageElements.text: The Ford Mustang is one of those cars that dreams are made of. It’s the Mick Jagger of cars: even after forty years out on the road, it retains its charisma and appeal. The rear-wheel-drive performance car continues basically unchanged from 2012, although the front and rear have been slightly revised, and the headlamps and taillamps have been modernized. There’s an optional 4.2-inch LCD information screen that offers fuel economy and performance information. The colorful screen’s Track Apps practically beg you to test the car’s (and your) limits with an acceleration timer, brake performance measurements—even a drag strip-style Christmas tree countdown feature. A V-6-powered version of this car gets 31 un-Mustang-like mpg on the highway. On the other hand, those who want to take the V-8-powered Mustang GT out on the track will appreciate the optional GT Track package, which adds an engine cooler, performance brake pads, and other upgrades. The most insane version is the Shelby GT500, which has a 650-horsepower supercharged V-8 and can exceed 200 mph. Slightly more sedate is the Boss 302 Mustang, with its 444 horsepower, six-speed manual transmission, and Recaro racing-style seats, not to mention reflective hockey-stick graphics that are meant to remind you of the 1969 Boss 302. You know what they say: If you remember the '60s, you weren’t there—but the Mustang can drive you back anytime you want.

title: 2013 Ford Transit Connect
subTitle: The business end of the Ford lineup drives more like a car, works more like a truck, and returns entrepreneur-friendly fuel economy

pageElements.text: Neatly bridging the gap between personal transportation and the work vehicle, Ford’s Transit Connect is a small but capacious truck that a small-business owner can love. It makes up for its somewhat ungainly tall body by offering a low floor and high roof, wide-opening rear doors and a great deal of configuration choice—meaning everybody from flower shops to window repair companies can kit out a Transit Connect that is perfect for their needs. The load height is less than two feet, you can get doors that open up 255 degrees wide, and the turning circle is tight enough for the middle of downtown. The Transit Connect is highly modular, with all manner of bins and storage racks to choose for a custom setup. It’s also offered in alternative fuel (LPG or CNG) and electric versions and, to Ford’s credit, with a Motoring Mobility package for those with physical challenges. Use it as a cargo hauler with seats for two, or get it with a folding second row of seats so it can carry four or five people. It even gets 27 mpg on the highway. The only thing you shouldn’t expect is driving excitement, since this front-wheel-drive work vehicle has a 136-horsepower four-cylinder engine.

pageElements.text: You may not realize it, but we guarantee that you’ve seen at least one Subaru Forester once a day during your travels. They may not belong to one of the more recent model years, but there’s a reason why so many people are still driving their ten-year-old Foresters in 2012 and it’s the reason why you should take a look at a 2013 model if you’re looking for a new crossover. It’s a basic vehicle that can take the wear and tear accompanied with carting around luggage, athletic gear, and even the family dog. If you’re an outdoor enthusiast, that is definitely a plus. The 2.4-liter Boxer engine will give you a fuel economy of 21 mpg city and 27 mpg highway, which is an increase from 2011’s rating. If you want to enhance your driving experience, look into the models with the 224-horsepower turbocharged engine. For your driving safety and convenience, you can opt for adding a voice-activated navigation system to your Forester and one of two winter weather packages. Possibly the best thing about the Forester, besides its durability, is the all-wheel drive, which comes standard on all Subaru vehicles and will be with you for the years to come.

pageElements.text: Honda’s CR-Z is the only hybrid on the market that is only available as a six-speed manual, making it perhaps the sportiest way to go green. The stylish coupe only seats two people — and maybe only two small people, with a slim 49.1 cubic feet of passenger space. The hatchback’s low back end limits rear visibility, but the tight squeeze fits with the character of the car, though, and the 122 horsepower engine is able to provide some fun for the driver while still handling well. There are also three available drive modes, so that the driver can decide whether to conserve fuel or pump up the performance. The CR-Z gets a wallet-friendly 35 mpg in the city and 39 mpg highway.  Priced at $20,000 to $24,000, the CR-Z keeps with Honda’s tradition of offering impressive fuel economy without forcing you to mortgage your house, but if extra seating or cargo room are of any concern it might make sense to look at one of Honda’s hybrid sedans. On the other hand, if you don’t have kids or equipment to haul around (or if you make the kids walk so you can keep your sweet ride) the CR-Z is certainly worth a look.

pageElements.text: The Honda Odyssey is the kind of minivan you always hoped you’d be able to drive. It holds seven or eight people, depending on seat configuration, tows up to 3,500 pounds, and boasts almost 40 cubic feet of storage behind the third row. There’s plenty of room for storage up front, too, with a large removable center console that can fit a bag and several water bottles.  For trips to Ikea or cross-country moves, the rear seats fold seamlessly into the floor to maximize cargo space. The Odyssey runs a V-6 engine with either a five- or six-speed automatic transmission. It has Honda technology that allows some cylinders to shut off when not in use, helping it achieve a class-high 19 mpg city and 28 mpg highway. Perhaps best of all is an available giant rear video monitor with a split-screen to avoid tantrums if your brood can’t agree on a movie. The Odyssey’s price is high, its design is far from sexy, and it can be a little slow to accelerate and decelerate, but otherwise it is just about everything you could ask for in a minivan.

title: 2013 Hyundai Equus
subTitle: The Hyundai Equus crosses the $60,000 mark for the first time, but it’s still a relative bargain compared to most of the competition.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Equus hit a major milestone for the new model year as a price increase officially put the luxury sedan’s base price above the $60,000 mark. That price can rapidly escalate if such items as 50/50 split rear seats, a rear-seat entertainment system, rear console refrigerator, and a power trunk lid are on your shopping list. In that case, expect to pay over $67,000 for the 2013 Equus Ultimate edition. Despite the price increase, the Equus is still a relative bargain compared to most of the competition, including the Lexus LS 460 and BMW 750i sedan. The 2013 Equus is a carryover model with only minor upgrades. Last year, the Equus got major powertrain upgrades. It is equipped with a 429-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine linked to an eight-speed automatic transmission.  Highlights for 2013 include a new White Satin exterior paint with a Saddle interior color combination. A new Gran Premio Gray exterior paint will also be available. Lots of attention is paid to ritzy touches on the Equus, including a leather-wrapped, French stitched instrument panel, a wood-and-heated leather steering wheel, and a massaging driver’s seat. The Equus is loaded with safety features, including nine air bags, smart cruise control, and a standard lane departure warning system. As Korean automaker Hyundai continues to burnish its image, it has rolled out the white-glove treatment for Equus owners. They can have the Equus picked up at their home or business for service appointments and get a complimentary loaner vehicle.

pageElements.text: A few years ago, there was much tittering about what Jaguar design chief Ian Callum would do with the forty year old XJ nameplate. Callum rose to the challenge by going out on a limb and in reinterpreting the Jaguar exterior design. What he came up with is a unique sedan that’s helped revive Jaguar’s lineup. If you like exclusivity, the Supersport can only be purchased by custom order, which will grab you a supercharged 510-horsepower V-8 engine, leather headliner, and laser-engraved veneers. It’s still missing desirable features like Google Maps and in-car Internet. You can grow an extra 5.1 inches in the long-wheelbase version. Like the XF, the XJ adds all-wheel drive to its options for 2013. The lightweight aluminum structure makes the XJ a more graceful car than it’s considerable proportions would indicate. The AWD-equipped XJ is expected to deliver 25 mpg on the highway, which is pretty darn good for such a big boss car. The company adds the British-branded Meridian audio system for an all-encompassing sonic experience. The limited edition XJL Ultimate model comes with a beverage chiller, power-operated rear table, flute holder, and two iPads mounted in custom leather-trimmed docks, complete with keyboards.

pageElements.text: The Passat is another Volkswagen that got a significant price cut for 2011, though it still hovers around the $30,000 price range. Unlike the Jetta, which paid for its price cut mainly in interior downgrades, the Passat paid for it with a smaller, less powerful engine. Luckily, the Passat retains its well-balanced ride and plush interior, and for the daily commute or shuttling the kids around, the tamed Passat will do just fine. The Passat’s base models don’t have fantastic gas mileage, but a TDI clean diesel option gets 31 miles to the gallon in the city and 43 miles a gallon on the highway, almost as good as some hybrid models. The exterior is smooth and well built, but largely unremarkable. Where the Passat shines is in its interior, which looks like that of a more expensive car. Available features include leather seats, chrome trim, a touchscreen radio, a sunroof and a navigation system. Bluetooth connectivity comes standard. The expansive backseat means that even adults will be comfortable, and the middle seat in the back row makes the Passat a touch more practical than the CC or other four-passenger sedans.

pageElements.text: The 2012 Jeep Liberty will soon be living out its last days in showrooms. Jeep has said that it will be replacing the Liberty with a Fiat-based model in 2013 or early 2014. If you don’t want to take chances with the upcoming model’s roadworthiness, the Liberty is still a good bet for drivers who like a little adventure. Not as off-road capable as the Wrangler or the Grand Cherokee, the Liberty can still hack it on less demanding off-road excursions. The Liberty could be improved by a few more gears (it is currently only available as a four-speed), but it offers fun options like a full-length retractable sunroof and available Uconnect hands-free system to make up for it. The Liberty won’t disappoint on space, with more cargo room than any Jeep but the Grand Cherokee, and it is tow rated at up to 5,000 pounds depending on the model. Its fuel economy is typical of Jeeps (which is to say not very good) at 15 to 16 mpg in the city and only 21 to 22 on the highway. New for 2012 is the limited edition Arctic trim level, with Yeti details throughout to emphasize its winter theme.

pageElements.text: Appropriately named after the Greek goddess of the dawn, the Eos is perfect if you want to feel those UV rays on your face. With the top up, the Eos is a fairly normal-looking car. Once the folding hardtop comes down, however, the Eos is shown for what it really is: one of the most spacious convertibles on the market. The Eos boasts a fun, revvy engine that won’t bore you behind the wheel. With ample room for four in a nicely appointed cabin, Volkswagen recommends the Eos for weekend trips for the whole family. In reality, the Eos would struggle to fit four suitcases with the top down (it stores in the trunk, taking up a considerable amount of cargo space) but with small suitcases and some ingenuity anything is possible. The Eos is the only hardtop convertible with a full-size retractable sunroof. The interior comes in four colors, including Red and Atlantic Blue for drivers with quirky taste. The Eos is a bit pricey compared to other Volkswagens, but with its unique array of features and surprising versatility, the Eos is a purchase you won’t regret.

The Crossover is the only SX4 that comes with all-wheel drive; if you go with one of the other models, you’ll have to settle for front-wheel drive. The car’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine will get you up to 29 miles city and 33 miles highway on a single tank of gas. However, given the size of this car as compared to some of its competitors, the mileage should be better. The upside is that many features that come in expensive comfort and convenience packages on other cars come standard on the SX4. On most trim levels, you’ll find your SX4 equipped with illuminated steering wheel controls, a leather-wrapped steering wheel with cruise control buttons and audio controls, and a remote keyless entry system.

pageElements.text: Although known for their compact cars, Suzuki engineered the Kizashi to be its flagship car for the 2010 model year. Since then, the Kizashi hasn’t undergone many changes and, like its siblings the Grand Vitara and the Equator, exists under the average buyer’s radar despite sales promotions that can reduce the price of the car by $3,000. With a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine, the Kizashi has a fuel economy of up to 23 mpg city and 30 mpg highway, making it great for those with long, cross-town commutes. Since long rides can be less than stimulating for the driver, Suzuki offers a Rockford ten-speaker sound system and heated leather seats on the Kizashi Sport SLS, which also allows you to stream music from your iPod via Bluetooth if the AM/FM radio doesn’t hold your interest. Long drives to and from work can also be hard on your car, but they shouldn’t be a problem with the Kizashi; this car held up after driving at top speeds on the Autobahn and rolling over cobblestone roads in England. You’ll be able to hear your music or news over the outside road noise thanks to the Kizashi’s sound installation even at high speeds. The French seams on both the cloth and leather seats add a nice touch to the car’s roomy interior.

subTitle: Whether it’s sedan or coupe, the C-Class combines refinement, luxury, and performance.

pageElements.text: No matter what variant you choose, the Mercedes-Benz C-Class is well-built, luxurious, comfortable, and quiet. Who wouldn’t want a car with those attributes? Maybe it’s not quite as racy as the BMW 3-series, but some people are seeking refuge and technology. The C-Class certainly has plenty of the latter. The standard “mbrace” suite of telematics features now provides Internet access, and you can use mbrace2 and your smartphone to keep the valet from joyriding during your hot-stone massage. (This is called “geofencing.”) The C-Class comes as a sedan or coupe, and there are engines of four, six, and eight cylinders. The 3.5-liter V-6 with direct injection and automatic start/stop, which is available in the all-wheel-drive C300 sedan, is a great choice. On the other hand, the rockin’ C63 AMG has a 6.2-liter V-8 that puts out 451 horsepower and takes no prisoners. A seven-speed automatic is included with every C-Class model. Sport sedans--notice that we’re pushing sport--have a flat-bottomed steering wheel and heartbreakingly beautiful ash wood trim. You’ll kick yourself for getting the floormats dirty. Optional driver assist keeps track of surrounding traffic and can guide the car back into its lane. Were you checking your Facebook page?

pageElements.text: So you’re looking for a dependable car and you think you’ve seen all that the automakers have to offer by spending hours watching sunlight bounce of one windshield after another? Well, don’t make a decision just yet. The Subaru Legacy has been a solid performer since it’s redesign in 2010 and will continue to be with its new changes for 2013. Under the hood of the 2.5i, you’ll find the brand-new, 2.5 liter Boxer engine which achieves up to 32 mpg highway with standard all-wheel drive, making the Legacy the most fuel-efficient sedan on the American market. One of the great things about mid-size sedans is that they accommodate both the short and the tall comfortably, but the Legacy is roomier than most, boasting 103 cubic feet in passenger volume. However, more car can sometimes mean reduced visibility. That is remedied with the new EyeSight driver-assist. Not only does this system provide you with lane departure warnings and identify obstacles in traffic, but EyeSight can activate the brakes to avoid collision. So before you decide to put a hard-earned down payment on a Fusion or a Camry, take some time to look at the safer, sportier 2013 Legacy.

But don’t let that scare you from a machine that was built to enhance what we do best: drive. First, you can keep your keys in your pocket while driving the BRZ Limited with its keyless access and start. Once you put yourself in the driver’s seat and feel the standard leather-wrapped steering wheel, all you have to do is push the start/stop button and you are ready to embrace your inner racer. The BRZ comes with a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission, but if you want to experience the BRZ as it was intended, go with the manual. Driving the BRZ should be fun, and the engineers at Subaru want to make sure you keep your hands on the wheel and enjoy driving. The BRZ comes standard with a GPS touchscreen that is voice activated so you can concentrate on driving when you need to find your way. title: 2013 Scion FR-S
subTitle: A sporty Scion you can’t help but love

pageElements.text: The FR-S is Scion’s first foray into the land of sports cars, and it is a bold step away from the boxy crossovers that have made a name for Scion in the US. The FR-S is a truly sporty automobile, with responsive handling and a light, speedy feel. It feels and looks like a more expensive car, and with 22 to 25 miles per gallon in the city and 30 to 34 on the highway, it won’t give you driver’s remorse at the gas station. The FR-S’s insides come from Subaru, who are building this car and its twin, the Subaru BRZ, in the same plant. pageElements.text: When the Range Rover Evoque Special Edition hits the market in October, it is expected to become an instant collector’s item, thanks to the work of fashion designer and cultural icon Victoria Beckham--yes, that Victoria Beckham of Posh and Becks fame.

The Evoque Special Edition bears Beckham’s unmistakable design stamp of edgy yet understated elegance. She worked on the cosmetic elements of the Evoque in collaboration with the Land Rover Design team, which apparently was mesmerized by the outfit she wore when they first met.

Beckham was wearing “dark clothes and no jewelry apart from a rose gold man’s watch,” said Gerry McGovern, Land Rover director of design. The watch became a sort of talisman for the team, inspiring the look of the car inside and out.

The Evoque Special Edition features such touches as hand-finished matte exterior paint and 20-inch gloss black forged alloy wheels with rose-gold accents, along with rose-gold-plated interior touches. The rose-gold accents are right in line with a hot trend in fine jewelry.
Beckham’s Evoque also gets mohair floor mats, a custom luggage set and a hand-sewn leather portfolio for the owner’s manual, signed by the fashion designer.
“I like that it feels luxurious, but also has quite a classic edge to it as well as a contemporary feel,” said Beckham.

The New York Times credits Beckham, a former member of the British pop group the Spice Girls, with making “strong clothes for strong women.” While she is not the first female fashion designer to turn her attention to cars — Dana Buchman tinkered with the 2007 Cadillac SRX — Beckham is the most high-profile color-and-trim artist in the auto industry at this point.

“Working with Victoria, the intention was not to change the fundamental architecture  and design of the Evoque,” said McGovern. “We wanted to create a special edition that extends its character in a new direction through understated, restrained color and detail changes.”
It makes us wonder, why don't they let Victoria Beckham design a Range Rover from top to bottom before some other auto company snaps her up?

contributors.bio:
I’m a jazz aficionado, a car geek, a food lover, and a goofy mom. I'm lucky enough--or foolish enough--to be able to turn most of my avocations into something resembling a vocation. Except for motherhood, but that's its own reward, right?

I was a record store geek back when there were record stores, and worked at the venerable (and late, lamented) Schoolkids' Records in Ann Arbor through college, while spinning jazz records at WEMU to the taxi drivers, barflies and night owls who listened during the wee hours. I then spent a dozen years as the corporate jazz buyer for the Borders Books & Music chain, a job that even in hindsight seems too good to be true.  After the music business--and Borders-imploded, I pursued another passion and joined the staff of AnnArbor.com as a food writer and community content coordinator. I spend a lot of time cooking, eating and writing, which also often feels too good to be true.
 
And now cars. I’ve been a car geek since I could walk. I caught the bug from my dad, who saved up the paychecks he earned pumping gas as a teen in western New York until he could afford a gorgeous vintage 1939 Oldsmobile. My first car was my parents’ old Dodge Spirit--an innocuous-looking car that hid a turbocharged V6 under the hood. That car took me all over the country--and fast. If I shoved a Kleenex in the tape player to stop the rattling, I could easily cruise at 120 mph, a thought that now--as a mom--strikes fear in my heart.

pageElements.text: Music and cars have long gone hand in hand. There’s something romantic about the idea of driving down the highway with the radio blasting your favorite songs. But you might have noticed that your favorite songs aren’t sounding as good as they used to, and it’s not just that your factory-installed radio can’t handle the beats. Chances are good that it’s at least partly your phone’s fault.

iPods and iPhones have revolutionized how we listen to music in our cars, for better or worse. The better: you’ve got a library of many thousands of songs at your fingertips. The worse: you’re giving up serious sound quality in exchange for all those songs. Unless you’ve customized your iTunes settings, you’ve been compressing your music as you import it to your computer, and the more you compress music files, the more sound quality you lose.
The solution: start importing your music at a lower compression rate. You’ll be able to fit fewer songs on your device, but they’ll sound so much better.

The default compression rate setting in iTunes is 128 kbps, which flattens out the music, losing important details and subtleties.  Try using a higher bitrate/lower compression setting to see if you can hear the difference.

You get the best results when using the Apple Lossless file format, but the resulting song files end up five times larger, dramatically affecting how much music fits on your player. A good compromise is to import your music at 320 kbps – you’ll get noticeably better sound without having to give up as much file space.

That’s all great, but how do you keep the volume on your iPhone from jumping or dropping from track to track? Well, it turns out that this has an even easier solution.  If you open the “settings” menu and select “music,” Apple has an option called “sound check.” Click that, and your sound levels will all be normalized.  No more jumping out of your skin when the Beethoven string quartet ends and Green Day begins.

Sure, you could invest in new car speakers, perhaps a subwoofers and sound dampeners in your car doors. But before you go to extremes, just make these two simple adjustments and see if the music doesn’t sound a whole lot better.
